I couldn't even power it off or do a factory reset. It's now inoperable. I submitted a service request a couple days ago and haven't heard anything so far. We'll see how the return/replacement process goes...
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 31 May 2019

one_reviews_text: I have owned a Oculus Rift for a few years now, which I really loved at the time.Over time I found that I would rarely actually use it, as it took quite an effort to set everything up (3 sensors).Being a Mac user, this came with additional issues, as Apple somehow refuses to provide some potent GPU's or a reasonable GPU upgrade path. So I found myself using a Windows machine each time I wanted to play (with nVidia 1060).  It has always been an impressive experience though.Last week I did get myself the Oculus Quest, and boy did a world of fun open for me.No more setup, no PC needed with beefy GPU, no annoying wires.Just take the headset, put it on, and you're good to go!When I received the Quest, it took about 10 minutes to get started for the first time (including unboxing), and in the passed days I have found myself using the Quest frequently.-> Note for Oculus: add a page to your quickstart guide, showing what button does what and showing how to power off the device properly, would have been good.The best part is definitely that the entire exercise of "getting started" has been cut down to almost zero time.Just take the headset, put it on, verify the guardian, and you're good to go. This was definitely not the case with the Rift.Speaking of the Guardian; it seems to remember earlier settings, which is nice when you're playing on the same spot again in the future. Being able to see your surroundings while setting the Guardian is awesome!  Something I missed with the original Rift.Since the headset includes an Android device and a battery pack, it is, understandably, a little heavier, but I have to say that I didn't notice this while using it.On that note: the headset has significantly improved for those wearing glasses. A special insert will provide a little bit more room.The controllers are different than the ones that come with the Rift as well, and I'd say they are an improvement as well.The battery gives me quite a bit of play time (about 2 hours), and if needed one can charge while playing (charger or Powerbank - it seems the USB-c charger/Powerbank should at least support 5V/2.6A). I haven't had a need for that, because after 2 hours of playing, it's nice to take a little break anyway.Charging the headset is relatively fast, it seems the provided charger is 18W, so maybe a beefier charger will do things quicker. I haven't tested that yet.As one can imagine, the graphics (details) are not as great as the Rift (lack of beefy GPU). Games like "Robo Recall" play very smooth, but the textures are of a much lower, but acceptable, quality. The quality is enough to have a very smooth and acceptable experience. Having said that; the picture is very clear and seems a little better than the Rift, but not by much. The headset does seem to fit better though than the Rift.The sound was actually a surprise. Where with the Rift one had little speakers over the ear, the Quest seems to have "nothing" yet the sound is surprisingly good. An optional headset/earbuds can be used, but I haven't had a need for it yet.Linking the Quest to my XBox One controller worked off the bat as well, which I needed since I wanted to sideload Half-Life and Quake (sidequest - sidequestvr.com). Obviously, the old Half Life and Quake games are very low-res, but it was a fun experience anyway as you can move around more freely (compared to "Robo Recall" where you have to jump from one location to the other).One cool thing Oculus did as well, is that when a title is available for the Rift and the Quest, your previously bought games will be available on the Quest as well (eg. Robo Recall).Another cool thing is the Oculus Quest for your smartphone. It not only gives you easy access to all kinds of settings, the store, your library etc, but ... it also allows you to view what the player is viewing or even cast the video feed to ChromeCast. This is great when wanting to follow a player or when wanting to help out those new to the VR experience.Now one downside is that the game selection is, at this moment, still a little limited.SideQuest adds a few extras, but it is not for everybody.Some games of the Rift are re-done for the Quest (Robo Recall for example), and some have a "version 2" for the Quest. For example the super cool demo "Face your Fears" (Rift) is available for the Quest as "Face your Fears 2" - unfortunately though, it's not even close to the original. It's a completely different "game".This actually bummed me out a little, since I used "Face your Fears" to show new VR users the cool immersive feeling when using a VR (it's awesome!). The new version is not anywhere close to that experience and has no resemblance with the previous version whatsoever.-> So to the maker of "Face your Fears" - please redo the original for the Oculus Quest as well!A few accessories one could consider buying;1. A hardshell case.I got this one, which first perfect and even holds charger and my XBox One controller: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07WCRS6D4/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&psc=1&linkCode=ll1&tag=tweaki-20&linkId=e269d682b3f9a6abf75cce49062b1d1c&language=en_US2. Optionally a lens protector - a little insert to make sure direct sunlight doesn't hit the lenses, and to prevent scratches when the Quest is stored. Still looking for this, and for now I use the little cardboard insert that came with the Quest.3. Some kind of hygienic wipes/masks/etc to prevent shearing sweat ;-)I'm still looking for something that would do the trick.4. A powerbank, if you want to remain untethered while playing with a drained battery.All-in-all, I'd highly recommend the Oculus Quest, and I'm curious what Oculus will do with the next generation.If you ever decide to sell the Quest, you'd find a buyer much easier, as there are no additional requirements (like with the Rift) for the potential buyer.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 22 September 2019
review_title: Coming from the Oculus Rift - Awesome!

one_reviews_text: I was on very excited to receive my oculus quest on release day.  I was sad to see that I received a faulty headset that had dried glue over the inside of the lens that needless to say makes the experience less than pleasant and blurry.  I have been in contact with ouculus support for nearly a week and no one seems to be able to get me an answer or replace my 400dollar system.  You can see what I'm talking about in this video.  The problem is most noticable on the right lens.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 30 May 2019

one_reviews_text: First of all, this is better than any other VR headset I have tried and that has a lot to do with the wireless nature of it. The biggest drawback here is that some games at some points gets very pixelated since this system is not very powerful. It is also a bit heavy so if your head is small... this will feel incredibly heavy and uncomfortable. I have attached a video showcasing what you get in the box and what the setup process is like. If you plan on getting this... do download the Oculus app on your mobile phone and create a Oculus account so you can skip that step when you get the headset!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 24 May 2019

one_reviews_text: So first impressions. Got my Quest delivered this morning, and the setup was crazy easy. You install an app on your phone, pop it out of the box, and are basically good to go.There are about 5 demos to check out as well as a basic tutorial about how the controllers work. I do recommend that you have at least 12’ by 12’ to work with for your play area. Installed Vader Immortal and Beat Saber... both of which are AAA releases and are sufficiently badass! Can’t wait to try more games in the next few days.Overall the wireless setup, decent graphics(with a bit of “screen door” effect) and 6 degrees of movement without separate sensors make this tech toy very exciting and great to bust out to impress friends. It’s not cheap, but if you have the money and want to get your mind blown I can’t help but recommend it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 22 May 2019

one_reviews_text: Wow! Just wow! I’ve wanted to love VR for awhile now. Started with Google Cardboard. Tried the Gear VR when I had a Samsung phone. Even bought a PS VR for my PS4. That one was definitely a step above the first two but I just never used it much. Last year I bought the Oculus Go thinking being untethered to a TV might be what I want. It’s collecting dust as well.The Quest? Can’t stop using it. I now realize it’s not so much the untethered nature that’s attractive, but the 6DOF and camera enhanced camera tracking.Yes, the graphics of this are better than the Go. Yes, I realize the graphics on a Rift S or Vive would be better, but I was never going to invest all that money into a gaming PC, I’m far too casual a user. That said, this is so immersive, it’s mesmerizing.Being able to draw out the dimensions of the room you’re in helps. You can literally walk around after doing so. If you get a bit too close to the edge, a virtual wall begins to appear to prevent you from walking into the real wall. The other thing that makes it a winner is the camera tracking and controllers. Being able to have the game recognize you leaning, or ducking is key, being able to grasp objects with your VR hands, having an articulating couple of fingers (not ten, but a couple) really changes the game.It’s still a gimmick for video playing, I downloaded a 3D movie, plus have tried things like the Netflix app and the Prime Video app. They’re fun for a bit, but the video quality/resolution just isn’t there yet. But for playing games (even casual ones like the addicting Poker game that’s free) - let’s just say if you’re like me (a casual gamer) this is probably the device to own right now.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 28 August 2019
review_title: Tried PSVR, Oculus Go, etc before Quest. This is the real deal!!!

one_reviews_text: A hardware platform is only as strong as the software available on it. There is a dismal amount of content on the platform, similar to the apps available on a first generation iphone. The hardware itself is amazing, but their "walled garden" approach means that the software will always be mediocre at best. The tech is ALMOST there, give it one more generation and we'll have a VR headset that isn't this walled garden nonsense!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 22 June 2019

one_reviews_text: My family and friends have loved this. Are the graphics bleeding edge? No. Does it boast a huge battery life? No.But! It does have great graphics and a few hours of battery life. It does allow you the freedom to be cable free and a view into the expanding VR market. All without having to invest in a costly PC system. To be honest, I mainly use this in short bursts and place it back on the charger. Or, I just use the VERY long charger cable while I play more intensive games, like Pavlov. Be sure to look into SideQuest so you can side load apps.Very happy to see where VR is headed. I will say this, this unit is very overpriced for the hardware, but I get it. It's still sort of Niche and new, so they can charge more. My only concern is the cheap controllers and how easily you can mistakenly remove the battery covers (most noticeable while playing tennis style games).I feel for the price, they could have either added a better battery compartment, Sleeves, Controller housing material.So far the little bugs are not really worth mentioning besides the device dropping wifi in clear view of the router (on multiple networks under low load). But, I would say the Price for sure. Had my roommate not agreed to pay half, I would not have owned this.If anything changes or after mid / long term use proves other faults to be an issue, I will update this review. For now, I am leaving this at 5 stars.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 27 August 2019
review_title: Perfect for what it is and what it represents.

one_reviews_text: I've owned other VR headsets (Vive and Oculus Go) and loved them both. For this reason my expectations for Quest were modest. How well could a mobile chipset handle not just gaming, but wireless gaming in 6DOF and tracking two controllers? I hoped for the best but expected to be mildly disappointed. Well, the Quest did not meet my expectations, it FAR EXCEEDED them! This is somehow a BETTER experience than I had in VR powered by a full fledged gaming PC. Visuals are great, no wires to worry about tripping over, tracking is PERFECT, and the convenience is too good to be true. Haven't been so impressed by a new product since the original iPhone. This is a game changer.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 27 May 2019
review_title: Everything I hoped for, and more

one_reviews_text: Where do I start? It came earlier than anticipated and the box was sealed, the product appeared to be in new condition, I say that because some people have reported getting used equipment or missing equipment, not so in this purchase. I charged it and put the batteries into the hand held controls and I loved that the doors of the devices were magnetic, they slid right into place and stayed! So far, we have played hours with the batteries that came with it, but I would suggest purchasing double A batteries, either Duracell or a brand name, I have actually thought about purchasing nicad rechargeable batteries. The games are so realistic, zero gravity will make you feel like you are floating and when you play the Darth Vader game, hold on to yoru socks, if you love Star Wars, you will absolutely love this game!  I swear, the reality of this is incredible.  Now the CONS. The head set isn't very stable, it feels like it might fall off when you are wearing it and it isn't very comfortable for long periods of time. The place where your nose fits has a crack that allows light to come in, often times making the experience not so great. ( I am going to use some foam to block that out) The straps seem flimsy and cheap, I am going to modify this headset, so it will work better, I might even use the straps from an older version of a VR set I have that has more padding and comfort. I will see. The fitting of the head piece is a challenge, because if you don't get it just right, the field of view can seem blurry in places, leading you to think the lenses need cleaning, when they don't. The weight of the helmet isn't that bad, I didn't feel like it was too heavy or bulky, I didn't think it distracted at all the experience. Again, I want to redesign the straps, and the foam, perhaps making it more secure and comfortable. Now don't get me wrong, it isn't that bad that I want to send it back, this is definitely a keeper! Now the games I found were a bit elementary, with the exception of the first person shooter games. I thought that the graphics seemed rudiment and elementary and would appeal more to those who are under the age of 13. I did find that the Vader game is the best, although the Seals type game I want but at 30 bucks, Ill wait a while. There are many free games and you can demo a lot of the games before purchasing them, and this is something I really liked. When you purchase a game, you can play it less than two hours and if you don't like it, you can request a refund, something I have never heard of before, but my 12 year old son told me about it, after he purchased plank and felt it wasn't what he wanted. Saber game is a great one to, its fun and you definatley get a workout! I love to fly, so I would love a real flying style game, I hope that eventually the makers will develop one. There is another game that is about climbing and it looks like a lot of fun. I think there are enough games out there to justify purchasing this head set. I loved that you aren't tethered either! This gives you a lot of freedom when playing games. Now about the reality of the Virtual reality. At times, I find that my mind interprets the environment as so real, I want to walk about and explore this world, it is so real, at times, my heart beats faster, because my brain has interpreted the environment as reality! I am so excited about this headset, I can only hope that as time goes on, they will develop more games, like Sony Play Station and X Box, but for now the Virtual world and the reality world they offer is incredible. I haven't used it to do google explore, I am really looking forward to that, my daughter did and she said, Daddy, it was just like being there, I was at the Eiffel Tower! So out of vie stars, I would give it four, only because of the headset and the limited games, but a solid four! Would I buy it again? You bet your socks I would.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 5 July 2020
review_title: ABSOLUTELY INCREDIBLE! So Realistic, it's scary!

one_reviews_text: As a long time Vive owner (currently using a Vive Pro and original lighthouses) I was honestly *shocked* that the Oculus Quest worked as well as it did. Despite being 100% standalone and portable, the 6DoF tracking on this thing is almost indistinguishable from my Vive, despite not having a dedicated room with mounted lighthouse sensors. It smartly switches off when not in use and boots up in seconds when you're ready to hop into VR, allowing you to play VR sessions up to three hours or just smack notes in Beatsaber for five minutes with literally no friction.The thing also works everywhere - on my first day I set it up in a conference room, my garage, my living room, and my basement - and the tracking has malfunctioning (like, maybe a second or two to sync up) perhaps twice in four days of usage. Amazingly, the image inside the headset is even more clear than my OG Vive and on par with my Vive Pro (granted, it's running lower rez, but still) and the framerate is flawless in most every game I've tried.In short, the Quest does everything we were promised at a totally reasonable $400 price point. It's an incredible device, and the freedom to go completely wireless and play anywhere (so long as there's not a super bright light or mirrored surface) far outweighs the minor loss of graphical fidelity from not having a desktop setup. I'm not abandoning my desktop PC or Vive Pro (I still use those for modded Skyrim and other high-intensity games) but I can't imagine playing games like Beatsaber, Superhot, or similar experiences on anything but my quest. Wireless is key.If you've been wanting to get into high quality VR and have balked at the price of a desktop PC and new Rift/Vive/Microsoft HMD, just get the Oculus Quest. It's great. And if you already have a desktop PC setup, get a Quest anyway.  The portability of the Quest can't be matched, and I love that I can be in Beatsaber (or a similar app) in under 10 seconds flat whenever I have a few minutes to spare. The Quest is as close to a "Ready Player One" headset as you can get right now, and an exciting step forward for VR in general.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 29 May 2019
review_title: Standalone Roomscale VR That just WORKS - On Par with Desktop VR

one_reviews_text: If this review were limited to just to playing the oculus itself I would give 5 stars.  It is super fun to play, has good games, and the multiplayer function is amazing.  I can play games with my friend across the country and it feels like he is actually in the room. You can even cast the screen up so everyone can see what you are playing and join along in the experience. And this is even considering we've been down a controller for half the time we've owned it (more on this below).BUT... you better hope and pray that nothing goes wrong and you don't have to interface with customer service.  Unfortunately the left controller that came with the system was malfunctioning out of the box.  It would work sometimes but would intermittently turn off or start jumping around/floating off into space.  I immediately went to the website which has a somewhat helpful troubleshooting section but none of the proposed solutions worked. I then contacted their customer service which quickly devolved into my worst customer service experience ever.The first thing is the only way to interface with customer service is via email/messaging- there is no phone call option.  Upon sending the message they quickly inform you that their response my take up to 2-3 business days. I will spare you the gory details, but essentially after suggesting all of the things that were already on the website and pretty clearly establishing there was something wrong with the controller, they said they would "look into it further" and get back to me in 3-5 business days.  It was only after emailing again to express my frustration that they responded that I did indeed need a new controller.  Essentially what could have been concluded after a 15 minute phone call took an entire week of back and forth emails.  Even worse was that every single message from the oculus support team was from a different person so I was dealing with a new person every time.The customer service then informed me that they would happy to send me a new controller AFTER I sent in the defective one and after 3-5 days of processing.  They provided a label for UPS Ground (AKA slow) and when I asked why they couldn't send a new controller once they were able to see I has shipped the defective one they said that they don't have control over the replacement process.I provided feedback via their requested link and they reached out to me to see if there was anything they could do. I expressed my displeasure about the fact that in total it will take me >3 weeks to get a new controller to replace the one that was defective out of the box and that the vast majority of the games are unplayable with one single controller.  I expected them to offer something helpful like a list of games that one can play with one controller and the response I got was (and I quote): "I appreciate your frank feedback about our support system, and we are continually working to improve the customer experience. I'll be sure to share it with the team."TL;DR- System and games are great and I would give it 5 stars.  However, the customer service was so bad I docked it two full stars.Should you have the misfortune of needing to interface with customer service get ready for a bumpy ride. We got a defective controller out of the box and it will take 3+ weeks to get a replacement and has caused a lot of headaches.UPDATE 10/7/20:Now my right controller has stopped working and I had to go through the same process again to get it replaced.  This time around they told me they will send a "refurbished" controller.  I asked to have the situation escalated to a supervisor given it was (what I hope) a rare occurrence of hardware failing twice, but was told it was not possible.  Now I'm in the process of waiting another 3 weeks to get my replacement controller and am unable to play most of the games.I'm changing my review now to 2 stars.  Again, love the gameplay, but you better hope nothing goes wrong.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 20 August 2020
review_title: Awesome gaming system- WORST customer service I've ever had

one_reviews_text: Do me a favor and google "oculus kickstarter" and watch the 5 minute promo video. You'll see why I say 7 years in the title of this review. This is essentially the culmination of 7 years of hard work, from prototype, to version 1.0, to various iterations and eventually leading to the next gen: a VR experience for the general public. It is not the end all be all VR, meaning...the Quest is not supposed to represent the best VR has to offer, but more like..."the essentials", or a fine balance of what you need to really get the A-ha moment, or to share this experience with those who are not in the loop. Honestly, even just a few minutes with the first demo experience is enough for anyone to really see - this is not just another gimmick device. It really is piece of technology that represents the next gen. Sort of like how when Steve Jobs first presented the iPhone, and said "we are announcing three products..." and the crowd all of a sudden got it, it all clicked. I feel that the Oculus Quest really brings that level of "enlightenment". It's quite special and even though it may seem like a high price tag...in fact it is only a small price to pay to really get that experience in your hands and those around you.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 31 May 2019
review_title: I've been waiting for 7 years! This is the one to take VR mainstream.

one_reviews_text: I love video games.  I also have a family and a demanding job.  My time for gaming is limited.  I already had the Playstation VR, so I am not new to VR.  This headset is amazing mainly because it is self contained and is wireless.  Some of the tethered VR headsets are going to be an improvement over this system graphically, but you are giving up the ease of use and freedom of a wireless experience.I keep the headset hidden in my entertainment center in the living room, there are no sensors, wires, etc that are left out.  Getting ready to play takes a couple of minutes and when you are done you put it right back.  You can take it on the road if you want to share the experience with a friend or on a business trip.  So far I have played beat saber, Vader Immortal, and Robo Recall.  I am very impressed with the experience given that this system is running off of a what is essentially a smart phone platform.  The graphics are pretty much PS3/XBOX 360 level of detail, but that really misses the point.  The immersion you feel in the middle of one of these games goes far beyond the graphical fidelity.  Think of this system in line with the Nintendo Wii.  The point is the interaction.  Not having wires attached to you if far more important in my opinion.The other key benefit of this system is it will expose non gamers to VR.  4-5 non gamers tried this out at my house last weekend and all of them were blown away.  Very similar to playing Wii bowling with your wife/girlfriend or mom/dad, its just easy to understand and very approachable.Having an uncluttered space to play is key.  Being on your feet and walking around through the virtual play space is the main benefit of a wireless system.  The system wants a 6.5 foot square to allow you to move around the room during play, but you can always go bigger.  You use one of the controllers to draw out the safe zone.  During game play you will see a mesh wall appear when you get close to the edge.  You can stick your head through the safe zone wall and the view will change to a black and white video feed of the room.  This is amazing, and really helpful if you hear a strange noise need to communicate with someone in your home.  The other feature I should mention is the headset has built in speakers.  This allows you the play games, but still hear ambient noise in the room.  If you have kids, its probably not a great idea to be blind and deaf at the same time.  You can plug in earbuds for a more immersive experience, but I wouldn't recommend it unless you are solo.I have found that VR is best in short chunks, like 15-30 minutes.  Most of the games feel more like arcade games and I think that is the right experience.  You are moving around and depending on the game it can be a pretty active experience.  Play a few rounds of Creed boxing, its not something you will likely want or be able to do for hours.  The ease of setup and wireless nature of the Quest is the ideal VR experience in my opinion regardless of cost.  Its less about the graphical horsepower and more about how you interact.  If you don't want to maintain a dedicated VR space and invest in a dedicated gaming PC, this is the way to go.  I can't wait to see the state of VR in 10-20 more years.  I think wireless is the new minimum standard after giving the Quest a test drive.  Good luck!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 10 July 2019
review_title: Perfect VR system for busy people

one_reviews_text: I'm a VR fan. I've tried many VR headsets. Phone, PSVR, HTC, and other Oculus headsets. I feel like I'm within the range to talk about this in depth.To start. The screen is very sharp. At least for current standards. You're not looking at real life obviously, but it gets the job done and the pixels are hardly noticeable. I cannot say the same for other headsets where the pixels are too noticeable and very distracting, however I feel like a theater experience when watching videos is a great trade-off for a bit more obvious pixels.That being said, the display and colors still look great, and I enjoy having vibrant colors when watching stuff or playing games. It is a good thing I notice far more than any pixels. It is just as good as all the TV's in my house and my iPad/iPhone, if not better in some aspects.When watching videos, it's definitely a thing you need to get into the habit for, as putting on the headset is a bit time consuming rather than just turning on a TV and sitting down. Until further improvements (which have been confirmed by Oculus to come in 2020 or sooner) are made for tracking, it is near impossible to watch videos at night, which discourages using it, because it needs to use the cameras and know where it is, and where the controllers are. This means keeping a light on, or having a really bright night light. The improvements Oculus are bringing for this issue will be astounding for other programs. The improvements include better tracking at night for controllers, and the ability to track hands so there is no need for controllers, which solves most issues and provides a true VR experience. Cannot wait for this. However until then, watching and playing at night or without any lights is impossible, so if you plan on doing that, wait a while; or don't! It's still fantastic.While I watch videos and movies and TV shows, the audio is great, the screen is great, and the feeling of a ginormous TV in front of you is great. However the best thing in my opinion is how comfortable it is.It's made of fabrics and soft straps, with no plastic pieces or heavy parts. It is still relatively heavy, but compared to other headsets, it's a dream. The weight balance is acceptable, and the straps are never uncomfortable. Watching stuff with this does not make my head hurt like the PSVR does, it's snug but not too snug.About the controllers, I like them. It took some time getting used to them, from other large controllers, but the responsiveness and little quirks about the controllers are wonderful. Just wish the straps wouldn't give out on me, they stopped tightening properly after about 2 months of regular use.The game selection is not very wide right now, but that's ok. The thing came out in May, and it has stuff like Beat Saber and SuperHot, so it's got the fun in those secured. However more quality titles are nowhere to be seen (yet!), and hopefully Oculus is able to bring big games like Minecraft VR, Skyrim VR, Borderlands VR, Etc. All over, because playing those on a PSVR or PCVR is not preferred after getting this headset, due to the fact that it's wireless.The wireless functionality has been the key factor for me. This thing is crazy cool and a humungous step in the right direction for VR. While the battery of the headset won't get you much playtime (2-3 hours, from experience) it sure does give me plenty of time to play wirelessly before plugging in the nonintrusive cable, trick for those wondering - play with the cord plugin into a wall behind you, and run the cord between your legs up to the headset, you won't even notice the charging cord there.As for the portability aspect. This is 1,000% better than anything else for letting friends and family try truly good VR without hauling a full PS4, or hauling a laptop (which most people don't use for VR, a desktop is smarter). I frequently bring this over to others and can hold the whole thing with one hand while carrying anything else I want in the other. I just use the original box it came in. Works fine for me! It's a great party trick, and not a one trick pony. People WILL ask you to bring this over when you visit, if they've tried it and liked it. People WILL ask when you'll bring it next. It doesn't get annoying, but it's funny! Seeing others try VR for the first time (and not garbage phone VR cases) with no wires, no limits, and with a good quality screen + good tracking, it is a wonderful way to pave the love of VR into everyone and get them hooked. I just wish there was a better way for everyone else to watch someone playing a game in VR. The current situation is having your friend put on the headset, with no custom headphones (using the built in speaker audio thingies) go to your phone, go to the Oculus app, and stream the Oculus view onto your phone. There is no audio (as far as I'm aware) transmitted to this cast, which is why I recommend the friend does not wear headphones, because the headset speakers themselves are the only way both the audience and player can hear what's going on. Not to mention the viewing for the audience is on a phone screen. You can cast your phone to a TV, but the lag from an internet connection, and high latency causing long delays onto a TV can make you feel like you're watching images of pixels with bad audio. There absolutely needs to be a revamped casting system for the quest, and I'm sad this is the best method!Unfortunately my first experience was with a phone VR case, and while I loved the concept of VR, it was a poor example for a first impression. I'm glad I stuck around for VR but not everyone is the same, this is a good way to get someone to try out VR and like it.Overall: There are some quirks and downsides. The battery isn't the best, more games could come out, nightime use can drastically improve, and the ability to cast properly are all things that I disliked or was not very happy about. However, the pros heavily outweigh the cons, and I am in no way going to get rid of this bad boy! It is a revolutionary product with many amazing features and a wonderful step for VR into the mainstream audience. If you're reading this and considering, absolutely do. It is worth every penny, especially since it's dirt cheap for the amount of use you'll be getting from it. I would do 9/10 but there are only 5 stars. So 4.5/5!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 20 November 2019
review_title: Best VR leap since the invention of VR!

one_reviews_text: Recommended mods: Deluxe Audio Strap is an absolute must. -- No way around it.  It will hurt your neck and head if you don't install this mod.Mamut Grips (or similar) are also kind of a must -- they let you let go of the controllers, and they just become a part of your hands -- your fingers move in IRL, they move in game. -- You don't have to grip the controllers the whole time.Rechargeable controllers -- this is a nice to have -- but just search for rechargeable USB batteries and small mini-right angle connectors for them. -- You can dremel out a small hole in the battery cover, so that the wire can come out and down and out of the bottom of the mamut grips. -- Then you can just plug in your controllers and have them always charged.Tactical Airsoft Helmet Counterweight -- lots of people are using all sorts of things for counter weights, including batteries -- but this has worked well for me; just put some velcro on the back of the DAS, and stick one of these to it, and you're good to go.  The nice thing about the airsoft counterweights is that you can calibrate them by removing/adding the little metal lego bricks.  Mine has spots for 5 of them and I use between 2 and 3.There's lots more mods you can do but those are the best ones, IMO.FYI, you can play PCVR games wirelessly with this headset using programs like Riftcat or Virtual Desktop (this has been there since like the second or third week after launch, can't remember).
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 6 April 2020
review_title: You need to mod it, but it's great.

one_reviews_text: This is my second Oculus VR set I have owed.  First was the GO and now the QUEST.  I am not a gamer.  I have never owned a XBox or any other system.  I have had this unit for over a month and these are my comments.  I bought the quest so I could be free to move around and have a greater experience and the Quest does not fail.  I have had no issues with my unit remembering different lay outs.  Graphics are incredible, the sound is really good (although head phones are the way to go.  No bugs or lag times  to report when system starts.  The hand controllers are easy to use with several extra buttons for the system to grow into.  Better life on headset is about 2.5 hours.  Headset is a little awkward after the first hour, especially in the back, top.  I’m sure 3rd parties are working on this.  There are many games to choose from ranging from Free to $29.00.  There are moves, videos, porn, And games to choose from that will keep you busy..  5G speed will only make VR and AR more popular next yearI gave the quest 4 stars because the games are to expensive.  I was a little upset to find out my games purchased on GO could not be transferred over, or at least a discount given.  The headset awkward pressure points and battery life all add up to one less star.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 15 September 2019
review_title: Oculus Quest gets 4 out of 5 stars

one_reviews_text: I purchased this with the intention of eventually using it for PC VR purposes (once that feature was announced). The quest's ability to function independently from a PC but also having the capability to function as a PC VR headset was what led me to make the purchase. Looking at reviews, it would appear that unless you're a VR Snob, you'll likely not notice the difference. For the price, I'm not sure it could be beat right now.To be honest, though, so far I've not used the PC VR ability.So far, I've been mostly using it for fitness. I've purchased only two games so far: Pistol Whip and BoxVR. Pistol Whip, in a nutshell is a shooting game that acts as my leg day and BoxVR, is a boxing game that works my upper body. Running through just one of the games will generally give me a better workout than a 30 minute ride on a stationary bike. The game aspect allows me to work, without getting bored, for an hour or more if my endurance will allow. My best workout so far (according to my fitness tracker) burned nearly 1000 calories and peaked my heart rate at about 189 bpm. This is fantastic, especially if you live somewhere where inclement weather doesn't allow you to get outside for a run. Likewise, if you're like me and get bored working out, the game aspect keeps me engaged.I do not own any other headset to compare this to so I am unable to give you a solid comparison, other than knowing I'm able to run the games from the Oculus store and don't need to be plugged into a fairly expensive PC. You can take it anywhere. Show it to friends, show it off at a party, take it to work and get a workout in on your lunch break if you've got somewhere to use it (That's what I do).Protips:Buy a lenscover, they shouldn't be more expensive than 10 bucks.Buy a face cover of some sort. The stock one is generally fine to start unless you're using it for fitness and get sweaty easily (I do).If you squeeze the controllers too hard the battery cover might slide off. Buying a cover for them or some scotch tape will help.(I was able to buy all three of the above in a package on amazon for about 25 bucks)After owning it for about a week, I bought a case for it since I take it to and from work. It's not that I mishandle it, it's that a case costs about 25 bucks and the 64GB Quest was still expensive (for me). 25 extra bucks protects it. Harbor Freight carries an Apache Case listed for about that (With a coupon). The Quest and controllers will fit neatly inside it.There are a host of customization options for the Quest. Everything from decals for the front, aftermarket head straps... etc. All of them are pretty innovative and more seem to pop up every week.One complaint I've seen is that there are a lack of games (on the Oculus store) for the quest at the moment. However I would point out that the Quest has only been around about a year and with it constantly being sold out, it would show the demand for games is there. Likewise developers are scrambling to come up with new and exciting content, both for the Quest and for the PC VR market. I would also note that, at the moment, there are developer options that can allow you to access other features or in development games. I would also argue that since it can use the PC VR function, if you get a computer capable of supporting that feature, your game library access expands exponentially.If you have other questions about the Quest or are curious about what accessories are best, there are a host of Youtube personalities who have already been there. Lookup "BMF" or "Eric For President" or "Virtual Reality Oasis" or "Cas and Chary VR" since most of them have tried the accessories or games out and you can watch them show you what they're all about and tell you if they're actually worth the money. There are countless others too, the Apache Case I found from the youtube channel "Tyco Tech."In all: 5 Stars. It does exactly what I want and more. I'm very pleased with this product.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 21 February 2020
review_title: Fantastic for games and Even great for fitness

one_reviews_text: So first of all, I'm a big time video gamer so when I started hearing about the Quest I really, really wanted one. For my 50th birthday this year, I bought myself one. And well, let's just say I live in Virtual Reality now. Or at least I want to. I can't even describe how awesome this thing is. I wanted to check out the Internation Space Station app which is free and my god, it's so mindblowing. I live in a tiny hut in the Shire, so to be transported to space and to get to do space walks felt like I had escaped into wonder. I almost burst out, "They should have sent a poet" ala Jodie Foster in Contact, but I digress. The next thing I did was download Vader Immortal and, after playing though the game with fricken' Darth Vader right in front of me, I decided to spend some time in Vader's Dojo. Let's just say I'm there every night fighting with a lightsaber and getting a wee bit of cardio. Seriously, if you're a geek like me, this thing will change your life. Come to the Dark Side people!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 6 September 2019

one_reviews_text: I am not what you’d call a gamer. I have a PS4 and play video games w my kids. Bought this on a whim, and it is mind blowing. All my family and friends have tried it, and even the most skeptical among them have said “oh my GOD” after a few minutes. The system is so smooth, the controller tracking is flawless, and the games are great. My kids love it. I love it.I have only three gripes: 1) the battery life on some intense games is a little low. Sometimes dies after 2 hours. Believe me, it’s very easy to play this system for two hours straight. 2) most games only allow one player profile, so if you’re using the headset for multiple people in a household, you all have to basically share the same progress in every game. Sort of annoying. 3) controllers should be rechargeable. They eat about two AA batteries per week.That being said, I love this thing. I would buy it again and again. It’s easy to use, and it is like nothing else I’ve ever played. It is like you are actually inside the games you’re playing. We love the Star Wars game, Job Simulator, and Racket. But all the games we’ve bought have been awesome.Our PS4 has been almost totally idle since buying the oculus. First thing out of my kids’ mouths when they get home from school is “can we play the oculus?!?”
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 23 October 2019

one_reviews_text: It took a few weeks to get this after ordering because it was backordered, but it was worth the wait. I've never had a VR system and I understand that this is not quite as technically advanced as something like the Rift; it has a lower-powered processor than the Rift, which from what I understand results in slightly lower resolution and processing speed, but so far I'm completely blown away! The headset is somewhat weighty, but with some adjustment I find it to be fairly comfortable. The controllers are responsive. The Guardian system that allows you to set play space boundaries so you don't bump into things is spot-on, though I wish there was a button to project it at any point, instead of having to get close to it for the barrier grid to show up on the screen. Casting to another device took a bit of work, as the instructions aren't exactly clear, but I got it working. A complaint there is that there is a distracting red dot that shows up in your field of vision to show that you're casting, but it's only slightly to the upper right of your vision; it could definitely be placed further out to it's less intrusive, or even having an option to disable it altogether. It seems that a number of folks have this opinion, and Oculus does have forums where you can suggest future upgrades to the devs.As to the game catalog, there are a number of fun and interesting titles, several of which I can tell greatly benefit from being untethered to a computer. It would be nice if there were more demos so you can try them out before buying; as of now there are only two or three, and a few more non-game experiences would be welcome, but the thing has only been out a few months so I suppose we should give it time. I'm definitely excited to see what games come out in the future, but so far there are some good titles available.One big question I had when considering which to buy was the memory: should I get the 64 or 128GB? I can tell you that I currently have 5 or 6 games and a few apps/experiences loaded, with a fair bit of room left over. And of course, as you complete games you can always delete and then reinstall them later, so I feel that spending the extra $100 for the extra GBs isn't really worth it; save that money to buy some games.In the end, I would say that if you're thinking about buying this or the Rift, you should consider if the lower resolution is a big factor (though I don't think it's that big of a difference, but I could be wrong since I've never used a Rift), and if you're OK being wired into a PC, reducing your range of motion. But if none of that matters to you and you're willing to plunk down $400 on a gaming system, buy this. Buy it now. You may have to wait for it to be in stock and delivered, but it's like being a kid waiting for Christmas again. I fully believe this is the future of VR gaming and will lead to further developments that will make VR more mainstream. I am extremely happy with my purchase, and highly recommend it!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 1 August 2019

one_reviews_text: Mixed feelings... won’t play with steam and you need to buy 3rd party streaming software to play games from pc.  It only plays “app” style games so if you Are wanting to steam you VR games you already own they will not work.  Even loading games you already own that can loaded onto the device requires the purchase of more 3rd party software.  It’s not very user friendly if you want to play games you have already bought and they oculus App Store doesn’t have a lot of quality games. Mainly B or C rated indie games. Also it does offer an almost open source web browser and fire fox but for an android based device not having a Google app in the store or available for download and having to download it though once again a 3rd party software is almost  laughable. It does have some great features like the tracking and not needing external sensors. The hardware is exactly what VR headsets need don’t get me wrong it’s great. they just need to focus more on software improvements. If it was compatible with mainstream gaming and didn’t require 2 different 3rd party software to stream and load it would have gotten 4 stars.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 25 August 2019

one_reviews_text: $400 is a lot of money for me. I bought it for 2 reasons - one is the health aspect and I have friends who are using it as their primary source for working out. The second and, equally important, reason I bought it is for meditation. When I heard there were meditation apps I was happy because I imagined meditating in all kinds of beautiful environments.I went to the Quest app store, only to find there are only 4 apps, ranging from $9.99 to $14.99. I tried one and liked it, but am disappointed in the limited selection. In fact, as I browsed the store, I was disappointed in the hefty prices for most apps. Free apps are limited...I only found16 in my search. After spending $400, I didn't count on having to spend so much on content.As for the headset, even with the eyeglass piece inserted, I found my lenses were not sitting in a way that gave me the sharpest viewing experience. (Just ordered new glasses, so this may be an issue just for me - we'll see.)So, overall, after the initial sticker shock, I see apps I would like to try but man, this is an expensive endeavor. After all of that expense, I expected a lot of free content and I am just not seeing it.Now I have learned there is another way to get apps called SideQuest, which means downloading APK files on the web, transfer them to the Oculus Quest, install them, then launch the app without using the Oculus Library. Ummm, ok.Additionally, I find the headset to be cumbersome and heavy. I used it sitting in bed for the meditation app, but still need to try it for active exercise. A lot to learn and figure out, but not sure this is something I can afford in the long run. Disappointing.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 26 July 2020
review_title: So far, a little  disappointed in the value

Now I am not technician at Oculus but that is not healthy for anything to have near the eye. Oculus has zero support so boxed the piece of junk and sent it back, if you have similar issues. Return it, these are not safe if they can get that hot.Hard to rate anything else since it was defective and nearly burned to the touch.Just found out its not compatble with Steam?? Wow.Oculus Seller, please do not comment to contact you as you do not help, only send generic answers forcing a return. So unless you are going to send me a free unit for my trouble, I wont be using Oculus products again, the GO over heated and so does the Quest.

one_reviews_text: The Quest is by far my favorite console and iv been ignoring my xbox for months! Oculus is doing a great job so far and facebook to! The games are ever increasing with better and better on the way! Cant wait to play Arizona sunshine and death lap! Facebook horizon looks good to! After i purchased my Quest a week later my brother got one! If you see any complaints its usually gamers who have a gaming pc and have known about vr and have a certain standard. Or people looking at quest as underpowered and little content. Well its BRAND NEW and is gonna be walking before it sprints! I can tell you the content comes quickly! Had only a handfull of games and now the library will be hit with great games in december we are seeing many! So. If you want to experience wireless VR games. And dont have a PC, or just want it wireless. Its the Headset/console to get. Plus it has LINK so you can plug into PC at any time if you have it. Join us Questers! And know the popular VR gameplay you have been Binge watching on youtube! We have a very active facebook group just look up ARNOOKIE and other Oculus quest community-based pages! This is Cody blaze K. if anyone from our group recognizes throw a thumbs up so the new people can see! Can't wait for the new comers that we need to make our VR games great!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 29 November 2019

one_reviews_text: Really wanted to like the quest. So many glowing reviews. The convenience compared to prior generation VR setups is game-changing.But they quest couldn't figure out where my floor was, so I had to put big QR codes all over the room with masking tape so the quest could "see" my floor. Ugh.And then, great, tracking seems to work, ish. What games does it come with? None? Wait, what? Ugh.Well, let's look into my oculus account and download my prior purchased games...Wait, *none* of my purchases work on the quest? I have to buy everything all over again? Ugh.Let's try the space pirate trainer demo. Ok, neat, but lag spikes make for nausea. And I can't put my hands behind or below me, as my controller disappears. Ugh.Had teenage son try it out, and he was nauseous after a couple minutes. "It looks nice, Dad, but I'm never putting that back on." Ugh.Too many ughs. Back it goes.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 17 September 2019
review_title: Inside-out tracking is spotty. Lag spikes lead to nausea.

one_reviews_text: I have both  - original rift and quest. So I'm comparing it to the rift only.Cons:1. Quest is very uncomfortable, it's impossible to wear it for more than 30 min, it's heavy and all the weight goes to your face! I do not have such problem with rift at all.2. VR sickness, it's much worse than with a rift. I don't know the reason, may be inaccurate tracking or low refresh rate 72Hz. Rift has 90Hz.3. Image quality, frankly I don't see any huge improvement over rift. Yes, it's better but not even x2 times better.4. Audio - garbage.Pros:1. Inside-out tracking, this is a pretty cool feature, but I doubt they will get a high precision tracking with it, it involves image recognition which is computationally expensive and inaccurate, unlike simple lighthouse tracking which used by vive and valve headsets. I know, it's portable but cmon, 99% of its users are using it in the same places.2. Oculus link, allows you to play games from SteamVR and Oculus Rift.I wish Carmack and his engineering team come up with better ergonomics, lighthouse tracking and minimum 90Hz refresh rate.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 11 March 2020

one_reviews_text: I bought the Rift S instead of this at launch day, preordered. I was on the fence between both units... I returned the rift S. It was terrible!!!! I waited to buy the Quest afterwards actually it was so bad. Until I heard about the Oculus Link technology and witnessed first hand ALVR running PC VR on a Quest.... Bought one, I love it, Best thing ever!!!!!  Adding hand tracking soon along with the Link make this a no brainer!  The Rift S is dead!  This becomes a Rift Q with a good USB 3.0 cable. or wireless with ALVR like I said. One pro tip I can give you all though. instead of connecting to your local wifi network. buy a good USB 3.0 wifi dongle. and then create a hotspot network in windows withit. Conect to your hotspot via the quest and make sure your PC is wired to your network instead of wireless. but that last part is not a big deal with this method actually. But doing this will remove any network latency or traffic from your wifi. Simply go into your hardware settings for your wifi card and manually set it to 40 mhz and to only use 802.11 a/n/c or any combo of those otherwise the hotspot will default to b/g mode which you don't want. If you do this you can play ALVR wireless PC VR no problem! It's literally amazing!!!!! don't listen to the other methods. do it this way.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 17 November 2019
review_title: better than a rift s and mobile

one_reviews_text: A pixel 2 XL with cardboard vr is 100 times better. So disappointed. UI is terrible. Getting started with any app is garbage. Screen door effect is bad. The ring effect is bad. No forward and back adjustment is an epic fail. Even when it's "off" the battery ran out... Spying much Facebook? Avoid. 💯% crap.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 1 September 2019
review_title: An old cell phone and cardboard is better. Sad.

one_reviews_text: Purchased for our daughter for Christmas 2019.  I thought since this was a Facebook company, the quality would be good.  My daughter likes the game.  Unfortunately, after five months of usage,  the right controller stopped working.  (my daughter does not play on the game everyday - the failure is not from excessive use).I googled support and found this issue has happened to quite a few people.  There are entire reddit threads dedicated to this issue.  We followed the suggestions and still could not get it to work.  We tried everything from changing batteries to resetting the device.Finally we contacted Oculus support and they opened a ticket. They said it appears we have tried all of the suggested repair protocols but with no luck.  They requested our purchase information and the serial numbers.  We have not heard from them since.  I would have expected better quality.  Buyer beware!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 1 June 2020
review_title: Poor Quality - Surprising given this is owned by Facebook

one_reviews_text: Well, it's like this...The Quest VR was amazing right up to the day it completely failed (26 days from the date of purchase) and upon research of the failure on the Oculus support site I found out that this exact issue (sudden loss of function of the home page, library, and store on the main control panel) has been a known issue since at least May and their suggestion to remedy the issue (simultaneously press the power button and volume control to reset the unit) killed the Quest. Luckily the failure happened prior to the expiration of return date and Amazon has ordered a replacement at no cost. The sad thing about my experience, even though I will receive a new unit, is that the failure issue has not been solved by Oculus.I can't express how "awesome" this technology is and how much I want my new quest to arrive, I just hope that the multibillion dollar organization that owns Oculus can fix this little bug.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 1 December 2019

one_reviews_text: I absolutely LOVED the original Oculus Rift, but the Quest and Rift S - I am not a fan. Those moments of presence in VR where you are jumping to return a tennis ball or quickly fire off an arrow: The tracking is often lost for a split second. It's not much, but enough to really make the experience less fun. Tracking also requires a ton of light to be effective. I'm so bummed that I was a proselytizing fan of Oculus, now I get angry every time I think about my experiences with Quest and Rift S.Doesn't require a PC to use, so that's something I guess ...
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 12 September 2019

one_reviews_text: I’m a big gamer, and I had heard of VR technology but not experienced it until this past Christmas. My brother brought his Valve Index and gaming laptop to a family gathering and after 10 minutes in Blade & Sorcery I was hooked. The problem with other headsets like the Index is that they require expensive base stations and are wired to a gaming PC. Plus, the Valve is $1000. I did a lot of homework and settled on the Oculus Quest for $399 and I couldn’t be happier with my purchase.The Oculus Quest is a great ‘mid-range’ entry to VR and honestly in my opinion the best bang for your buck. The Oculus Quest is a completely wireless system. You put on the headset, turn it on, and are immediately thrown into setting up a guardian (play space) and playing immersive tutorials. It is intuitive and requires no other expensive hardware to enjoy the experience. This makes it very easy to share the experience with friends and family (low barrier of entry).The best part about the system? If you ARE a gaming enthusiast with a decent gaming rig, you can link your Oculus Quest to your gaming PC to play more graphics intensive games. You can do this through the new Oculus Link feature with a cable or even wirelessly with the Virtual Desktop app in the Oculus Quest App Store. The wireless setup takes a bit more hoops to jump through, but once setup it works fantastically. There are many tutorials online that explain how to do this.I can go to a family gathering and share Beat Saber with loved ones, but then come home, boot up my gaming rig, and play No Man’s Sky VR wirelessly in the office.This Oculus Quest really does offer the best of both worlds for the best price. Honestly, the 64Gb version is more than enough space. Don’t waste the extra $100. Most VR games are smaller in size and the more intensive games you will be running on a gaming rig anyways.One thing to note is that the Quest’s tutorials recommend kids be 13+ to play. This headset is an expensive piece of hardware that requires care. The Lens are easy to scratch if you don’t take care of them and the controllers won’t take a lot of abuse (punching walls, etc). Keep that in mind if you are looking to purchase the system for children.Also, the lens technology used can feel a tad ‘blurry’ when trying to read white text on a dark background. It results in a halo effect. From all of the research I have done online, all VR headsets are like this currently. It takes some getting used to.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 23 February 2020

one_reviews_text: The answer is yes and no, but mostly YES. The only downsides when compared to the PSVR is the refresh rate and the weight. But both of those cons are offset by what you gain. Namely the higher resolution and the quest being completely wireless. It is front heavy and you will feel the heft. It's not a dealbreaker but it's something you'll get used to. Adjust the straps properly and you'll be fine. The ease of use cannot be overstated. The setup for the unit and play area are easy as can be. The "intro" to get you used to the controls ran a bit long for me as I wanted to just get into the meat of the interface. The speakers on these are a revelation. So much so that I don't think I'll ever need to get ear/headphones. One less thing to put on my head!  As of this review, I do wish there were more games (something the PSVR has in spades for obviously being in the market longer), but what is there is enjoyable and worth owning the quest for. Another upgrade the quest has over the PSVR is the tracking. You don't need to face a camera and therefore tracking loss is kept to a minimum (if ever).  I love that it's completely portable so you can share the experience with friends and family outside of your home.Overall it's like a refined version of the PSVR but with a few tradeoffs to achieve the form factor and pricing.  I thought I was set with the PSVR, but I was really longing for that untethered VR experience. So glad I bought the Quest.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 8 August 2019
review_title: Is it an "upgrade" from a PSVR?

one_reviews_text: Edit, 12/28/20:I've had this device for nearly two years now and have a few more comments to make.  First, it's still a great first-gen standalone VR system, with the ability to play graphically-intensive games at a usually-decent frame-rate (expect frame-drops frequently, though).  I'm still rating this a solid 4 out of 5 stars.  It still has issues with smoothly running games with a stable frame-rate, with intermittent stuttering.  Honestly, it annoyed me enough to replace the system thrice (thanks, Oculus) to try and find a system that didn't stutter, but every one I've owned does to a degree.  Four "defective" devices in a row seems unlikely, so...I've finally come to accept it's just the limitations of the hardware, running all this stuff on a mobile VR system.  I wish that lightbulb had gone off sooner, as I feel kind of bad now for requesting replacements on something that isn't actually a bug, apparently.  So, keep in mind: If you want a lag-free mobile VR experience...sadly, it's still several years off, I think.Original review:I was lucky enough to receive my Quest on release day and immediately booted it up, having bought a ton of games earlier when the store opened.  Set-up was a breeze (only took about five minutes or so, maybe less), and then I was in First Steps.  Wow, what a cool experience!  I actually replay it on occasion (I love that you can do that!) because it's just so fun.  The controls were fairly intuitive and I find the experience of physically grabbing objects to be wonderful.  Coming from the Oculus Go, the 6 DOF for your two controllers is truly a game-changer.The addition of room-scale to VR is awesome!  I've only had Google Cardboard-like headsets and then the Go, so I had nothing to compare it to.  Wow.  Just...wow.  I play Super Hot daily and it still blows my mind that I can actually drop to the floor to dodge bullets and then roll behind cover!  I have started to use the Quest as an exercise device, with Beat Saber and Super Hot being my favorites (for a game where "time only moves when you move", Super Hot is a surprisingly intense workout).  I await the Quest 2 and will buy it day-one.So, for my glowing review, why four stars?  I'm not sure if my device is slightly defective or if I'm just sensitive to screen-tearing and stuttering, but I just can't ignore the stuttering that happens in (admittedly graphically-intense) games like Job Simulator and Drop Dead: Dual Strike.  For example, when loading up Office Worker in Job Sim, the environment lags a bit when moving around at times or when a lot of things are happening.  In Drop Dead, it's also present, to a noticeable degree.  Again, it in no way makes the Quest unusable, but I was immediately disappointed to spot flaws in my brand-new device.  Or is a certain amount of stuttering supposed to happen and expected?  I really don't know, as I've never played games this demanding on a stand-alone headset before.I don't know if it warrants a return or not.  Aside from the stuttering and glitches (my controllers lose tracking in Beat Saber with annoying frequency and reinserting the batteries doesn't fix it), the Quest is near-perfect and I have never had a gaming experience like it.  If I do return it, I'll buy another physically from a store, I think.  Just in case.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 30 May 2019
review_title: This is a top-notch product!  Aside from a bit of stuttering....

one_reviews_text: Being an early VR adopter and owning the CV1, I was scared of the graphical downgrade, and possibly worse tracking, on the Quest.But oooohhhhh boy, those are NOT a problem!The graphics may be worse but THE RESOLUTION IS AMAZING!  Almost NO GOD RAYS!  I can hardly block the tracking EVEN IF I TRY!  How on earth does it track me when I cover the cameras WITH MY HANDS?!  Amazing.  I mean, holding my hands over my head for a few seconds will cause it to lose tracking, but aside from that, I have never had, or at least noticed, a loss of tracking.  And it works just fine in dark rooms, after all.And you'd be amazed at how many games you can fit on the 64gb version.The only thing I don't like is that I can't seem to connect an external SSD to the device to watch movies...  No reason that shouldn't work.  Hopefully they add that feature soon, or else I might have to invest in a portable NAS.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 18 October 2019
review_title: Wow.  I actually don't notice the graphics!

one_reviews_text: Oculus done a great job making a VR headset wireless, but the titles and picture quality are just not good enough to support the price. I got mine on the release date and got bored playing it after a week or so. The reason is because there aren’t many good titles you can play. The most enjoyable title is beat saber, but i got bored after a while due to the lack of songs and it has tracking problem sometimes. The headset is quite heavy and it also freeze sometimes. All in all, VR technology is not mature yet...
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 10 June 2019

one_reviews_text: The Quest VR:it is awesome and as I learn more about it, I enjoy it more. Game library is still currently small, BUT as of writing this, this system is only a year past release, so it's still growing. 120+ at the moment. Plus SideQuest stuff.For a stand alone, it's great. A little pricey, but still a good investment. The haptic response (vibration) in controllers is a huge thing with me. One of my fave game, Real VR Fishing, really gets you into it and while I haven't caught that damn shark yet, it's time is coming as my skills improve.If you want to play Half Life Alyx, you need the the link cable. I think party link is the cheapest. (Gaming pc is needed for steam games) but this CAN act like a Rift if u have the PC. I don't, so haven't tried this aspect of it.The seller:While the shipping was quick, my issue was price. I paid little over $500 for mine, in the week before it arrived, he continued to raise price to nearly $650 on his remaining sets. Price gouging on electronics was ridiculous when the quarantine started and I wasn't buying for that reason. I had a 4 month jump on quarantine before everyone else, just cause of my situation.My advice, look for the best price. Don't pay more than $550 for this. I saw some sets going for over $900 and that's just nuts. Do your research before buying.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 3 May 2020

one_reviews_text: Oh My God. That's the first thing pretty much everyone says the first time they try the Oculus Quest. It's a truly amazing experience.I bought my Quest as a family Christmas present last year. Okay, let's just say I bought myself a present last December and called it a family present. :-)  It's Beat Saber's fault. I swear.I'm not going to talk about all the good things. There are tons of people doing YouTube videos that can tell you about that. I'm only going to give you a couple of warnings and maybe a suggestion or two.-Warning one: the battery life is good (about 2 hours), but if you and some friends/family are playing, you can readily burn through that. There are ways to resolve that, including external batteries. See the various YouTube videos that talk about accessories.-Warning two: limit play time (initially). This wasn't just me. Playing too long at first can give people motion sickness, even on games rated Gentle. Once you've had it for a while (not all that long), this goes away.I'm also going to recommend you watch some of the YouTube accessory videos and spend a little more money. I haven't done it yet, but I recommend face shield things that can be more easily cleaned. You might get a little sweaty, and the next person might be grossed out by your sweat. You'll probably want a travel case. i bought the one from Oculus.And get rechargeable batteries for the controllers. You'll otherwise go through a LOT. I went with Amazon Basics. I got a 4-port charger and 4 batteries, so I always have 2 charged batteries waiting for me. Now, "a lot" isn't daily. The controller batteries last 3-7 days. But that's "a lot" if you use normal, non-rechargeable batteries.Different people will like different games. My favorite remains Beat Saber. It gets my fat old body moving. The space pirate battle trainer thing is fun, as is Gun Club VR. My adult daughters like Moss. I think that's a cute game, too, but I struggle with some of the puzzles. I'm old and slow or something, I guess.If you're having family parties, I tried sharing to my Apple TV via my iPhone. That worked, sort of, but it tends to drop out, and there's serious lag. I bought a Chromecast, and that works much better. It's the only thing we use the Chromecast for. Being able to let other people see the game is fun.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 27 September 2020

one_reviews_text: First, I love the actual experience of using the headset.  The experience is so much better than I even imagined.  The games are a bit expensive, but so far worth the expense.  However, the speaker on the right side has failed already, and I keep the sound turned way down.  It failed after less than 4 hours worth of use.  I can still use headphones so I haven't returned it, but for this amount of money, it should have lasted longer.  I would still recommend it for the experience, but I am a bit disappointed in the quality of the equipment.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 25 May 2019

one_reviews_text: Raise your hands if you've read this book more than three times like me?Needless to say the concept of VR described in the book and our virtual reality reality were far apart: an octopus of cables and sensors hooked up to a required $1.5k computer which few of us had. In the end, you ended up broke looking like Neo in his battery pod powering The Matrix. So when Quest was announced I thought, eureka!! I pre ordered and for once I was the first kid with the Atari 2600 on my block. In a word, glorious. The second word is "scary". The freedom that having no wires provides makes it almost too easy to go down a rabbit hole and lose entire days just playing, messing around and avoiding daylight.Many reviewers have already rattled off the technical pros and cons. There are more pros than cons. Is it perfect? What in this life is?? My face hurts from having this heavy piece of plastic and glass hugging my face for several hours. The battery runs down too quickly  (about two hours) . Yeah yeah, get a battery pack and enjoy yourself.The one major pro that is yet to be fully understood is that now you can hangout in "places" and experience "things" so frighteningly real that the teenage version of me would never have finished school or formed a family. It is a great system and the potential is truly astounding. Buy with confidence.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 28 May 2019

one_reviews_text: I really, truly, absolutely love this VR headset. It’s the first and only VR experience I’ve ever had, but it really is phenomenal. The only drawback is selection of games, and most games are more experiences than anything. That said, I love being able to invite friends over for their first VR experience and love to see their reactions to complete submersion.  Some really graphically impressive games have been released, and new and innovative tech and updates are constantly being added. This is, by far, the greatest gaming innovation since what I recall being a game stopper in my lifetime.  I’ve spent a bunch more $$$ in add-ons, including the HTC Vive headstrap, external battery pack, and a new face pad, and still this is a great deal. I’m so excited for newly released games and Oculus has simply been killing it with their support for this system. RECOMMENDED TO ANYONE AND EVERYONE!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 19 November 2019

one_reviews_text: [Edit] 10/21/2019I am going to up my rating to 4 stars. Oculus is doing a good job at listening to their Users. I wetn to https://oculus.uservoice.com/ and noticed others requesting the same. i also noticed they (Oculus) respond and show they are listening.If they do eventually go to a Multiple Profile OS I will bump it to 5 stars. This product is amazing outside of that. VR is amazing on this.(September 2019)I am not happy about this product but I do want to be fair with this review. So before I tell you why I gave this 2 stars let me say what is good about this product.The GoodThe VR is great. The device does a great job transporting you to a VR world with a great view and cozy fire place in the Menu Room. They selection of Apps is encouraging and I know the library is growing.I have had the PlaystationVR in the past and the tracking was so bad I got sick a lot. With the Quest I have had no issues with the tracking and my VR legs are getting strong.I also love the TV feature in the menu. This puts you in a comfy living room with a mountain view and a monster screen in front of you. From there you can watch ESPN and other TV Apps. It is nice if you want to watch something insulation from others. I just hope the selection of Streaming Apps does increase. Would love to see Youtube TV on this App.The Guardian System is really a brilliant idea. The headset has multiple I believe IR cameras and when you turn the system on it allows you to create a virtual wall to protect you from going too far in games and hurting yourself. if you go too far this virtual wall will appear in game warning you. And it seems to remember the room when you go back to the headset later.Now.... The Bad.Honestly it's just one thing and it is so big IMO I recommend holding off on purchasing this item until Oculus/Facebook address this issue.You can only have one User profile per device. If you want to let others in your house use it on their own profile you have to Factory Reset the device and start over. And!! That profile will have to buy the apps again if they want to play them. When you buy a game it is assigned to the profile not the device. This device was advertised as a Console VR system. This is not a console VR system. This is a personal device for one person by design.I bought this for my family and the way it is designed I would have to buy one for each member of my 7 member family..... Not a chance Facebook.This product has the chance to make VR popular. But not without the ability for multiple Profiles.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 10 September 2019
review_title: [Update]Product is great. Just needs Multiple Users.

one_reviews_text: First, let me start by saying that I love the Quest experience and games.  This is really is a top notch VR experience.  So, why the 1 star?  I have a Netgear Orbi, and wifi drops every 10-20 minutes forcing me to manually re-connect.  If you google this issue, you'll see that many others who use a mesh type network have this same issue.  Furthermore, they have been aware of this issue since it's inception, and it still hasn't been fixed.What that means for me is that I have to avoid buying any games that require an internet connection.  It's also a pain when downloading games, and there's no way I can watch a movie or do anything else with it until/if this issue is fixed.  And like many others, forget about trying to get any support.  I put in a support ticket over a week ago, and haven't had a response (they say 2 business days).If it weren't for this issue, I would rate the Quest 4 stars.  It wouldn't be a 5, because the other issue I have is that I wanted this for the whole family, but it's only tied to one account.  So, it does not lend itself to multiple users/accounts for games, making this device pretty much just for me only.So, if you don't have a mesh wifi network, I would very much recommend the Quest.  If you do, buyer beware!!!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 4 January 2020
review_title: Known Issue with Netgear Orbi/mesh wifi networks

one_reviews_text: Whether you're new to VR or are a long time enthusiast, the Quest is an amazing piece of technology.Having experience with a friend's PSVR and HTC Vive, I thought the technology was very cool, but a pain to set up. I always wanted VR, but it's too expensive for someone like me, who doesn't already have a PS4 or powerful PC. I don't really have much time for tethered consoles anymore, so it doesn't make sense for me to invest so much in something I would rarely be able to enjoy.
