After spending two years with my Nintendo Switch, I can't go back to trying to find time for console gaming.The Oculus Quest has finally made portable 6dof roomscale VR a reality without feeling like it's compromised too much. While there's a noticeable downgrade in graphics, the freedom from wires and the ability to turn any room into a play space more than makes up for it not being as powerful. Thankfully, the resolution is really high. It's higher than PSVR, or the original Rift/Vive. This, and the freedom of movement and wireless game play make it feel more immersive than console/PC VR.The games available, at the moment, are ports of many games that were previously only available on PC/PS4. It's amazing how well they look and run on mobile hardware. The difference between the Quest and PSVR/Vive feels very similar to the difference between PS4 and Switch games. It's a compromise I'm happy to make for an all-in-one VR game system.The Touch controllers are smaller than the PC counterparts, but work amazingly well. Many VR games were built around these controls, and apart from the smaller size work just as well.The inside out tracking and guardian system work almost flawlessly providing 1:1 tracking and a safe play space. Set up takes a minute, tops, and doesn't need any sensors.As someone who works at a group home nearly 70 hours a week, my overnights are now a time of respite. I can keep an ear out for my clients while feeling like I'm somewhere else. This has had such a theraputic effect that it literally feels life changing. I love my Nintendo Switch. It's awesome to be able to play console quality games anywhere, but the Quest gives me a change of scenery. It is also very helpful for someone with a sedentary lifestyle. I'm moving my body more and it feels great.I would highly recommend this to anyone with an interest in VR. It has the power to convert even people who don't play videogames regularly. We're living in the future, and it's awesome! I feel like I have a portable holodeck that's not only fun, but theraputic. I highly recommend the Oculus Quest. This could be just the device that will take VR from a niche hobby to a mainstream fixture in entertainment.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 3 June 2019
review_title: A Potentially Life Changing Game System

one_reviews_text: Got this for our son for Christmas this year.  He absolutely loves it and hasn't put it down since he opened it. Well except for the 2 hour or so battery life. The charger that comes with it charges very slow. He decided to use his fast charger from his macbook air and it charges it way faster.  It came with all three episodes of the Darth Vader game.  I tried it and like it as well.  The graphics are not xbox 1 quality but they arent Atari quality either. I bought him a travel case for it as well. Once the headphones come back in stock I will get those because I think the surround sound will be way better.  I think I will rig a battery pack to make the gameplay last longer. I would recommend it.  He would recommend it as well. I'm going to get a few more. A downside is only one person can be registered to it. If you want to add another family member you will have to reset it to factory defaults and clear out the other person. This will erase all their progress and games. However, you can play their games on their account if they let you. So if you have more than one child or adult that wants it they will have to have their own. There also isnt any multi player games out right now. We also purchased a warranty with it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 27 December 2019

one_reviews_text: Oculus Quest is the best way to experience VR. However, quality control issues will ruin your experience.Pros:No PC neededFun games like beat saberFun exercise games like supernaturalAdjustable PDOculus Link for PC VR games too!Cons:Very Poor quality control ruins everythingThe oculus quest is the VR headset to get after the launch Oculus Link... not only can you play PC free, you can also play PC VR games like half life alyx on the quest - it even works with the USB cable out of the box! However poor quality control ruined my experience. Right out of the box I noticed a lot of glare. while "god rays" are expected due to the way the lenses work, what I was seeing was from the inside of the right lens being cloudy. The effect is like wearing glasses that you smeared your finger oil all over.Until QC can be improved, I cannot recommend the quest.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 2 July 2020
review_title: Poor quality control, one of the lens is cloudy causing glare

one_reviews_text: I have both a Vive, and a Vive Pro with an Nvidia 1080x graphics card.  This is better than that.  It looks better, it plays better, there are no cables, and it is VERY portable.  No perceptible god rays.  No perceptible screen door effect.  I do not notice the difference in refresh rate whatsoever.  Maybe it's there? but the experience is so vastly improved by the lack of cables and the fact that I can use this anywhere that I do not notice it.  I should note that I had an Oculus dev kit2 and a Samsung Gear VR, so I've been at this for awhile.  I know the difference between good and bad VR.  This is VERY good VR.  I paid $800 for my Vive, and over $3000 for the computer I run it on 2 years ago.  This miracle cost me $400.  I can't see why I'd need a 128G version.  Do yourself a favor if you like cool stuff that works awesome.  Love the controllers too.  I got one of those silicone covers for the headset and controllers too.  Good investment!  I use this for working out (Beat Sabre, Box VR, Thrill of the fight)  I have all of these games on Steam VR and they are much more enjoyable to play on the Quest.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 29 January 2020

one_reviews_text: This product shows free returns for the Amazon return policy. I guess I needed to read every tiny detail because they charged me back $124 as a restocking fee. obviously it does not cost them that much. I ask if they would just apply that charge to the occulus ghost but they would not cooperate. The hand devices were heavy for my small hands and or not easy to use, especially if you have a little bit of arthritis in your hands.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 24 May 2020
review_title: buyers beware of free return policy.

one_reviews_text: This is a different kind of review meant for people who could only choose between an Oculus or traditional (PS5, XBox). I had to choose between the two and I opted for the Oculus; it's a decision I regret painfully. It isn't that this is a bad system. We all know that the speed and graphics couldn't compete with the traditional model gaming, but I was willing to sacrifice that for a full-immersion experience. And, ironically, that's why I regret it. The Oculus is just "too much" for me in every way. It's too long to get up and running, it's too slow, but most of all, it's too immersive. I like my gaming experience to be fun and casual. I like to hit pause easily and grab a snack, look out the window, or check my phone. It gets exhausting to put on the headset, check the batteries, check your radius of play, adjust the headset, wait minutes to navigate and load your game, and then have to wonder what you're missing on the outside world. The first hour of having this was awesome. Since then, I just don't find it worth the time to play. My advice? Go with PS4, PS5 or the XBOX. It's just easier and more fun.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 19 December 2020

one_reviews_text: This is my first time using a VR, the Quest is VERY uncomfortable to wear on my face. It's a heavy device so I don't recommend playing on it for too long as it will leave red marks on your forehead and cheeks (honestly it feels like it tugs at my skin). That aside, the games on it are $10-30 bucks so if you don't plan on spending anymore after you get the VR Quest you're out of luck here unless you connect it to a free game on a computer. The setup on the computer took a while especially since it did not come with a USB-C cord;  low-grade ones will not work so don't even try.After buying an appropriate USB-C cord for the VR Quest, it finally connected to the computer so I could play online games. As for the console games, I played the demo games and all were fun especially BeatSaber which I ended up purchasing with my VR. The battery life lasts two hours at most and then it needs to be charged.  All in all, love the experience--I don't think it's worth $500 even as a novelty item---definitely not. The uncomfortability wearing it is huge for being on your face even for 5 minutes.4.5 stars for the experience. Would be 5 if it wasn't so uncomfortable to wear and expensive for what it's not worth. Will update later if I have anything else to add.::JUNE UPDATE:: The controllers become disconnected often on fullbattery. This has nothing to do with connectivity as I connect my Oculus to the bluetooth? (which I didn't even need to do before..) Sometimes I play and my hand just disappears on screen, or worse, both of them do. Strange since I didn't even own it for a year and I take very good care of this thing.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 16 May 2020
review_title: Doesn't come with a usb-c cord....unbearable to wear.

one_reviews_text: I've only been using it a few hours, so I might amend this later to give an updated review. However, it's a lot of fun, and I like it a lot. The price is right..The good:it is easy to setup and go. ( I had an initial problem with the left controller connecting, but unpair it and repair it worked fine after)you don't need a pc. just a android or apple phone..Good selection of games to use.Graphics are great.the headset is surprisingly comfortable, you get used to it. It's just a matter of getting the right adjustment.The neutral:Even though you're not tethered to a pc, You still need a fair amount of space to use this.  Most of the games recommend a 61/2 by 61/2 foot guardian space to safely play.  I'd would say based on a person's  height  that the space be at least a foot or more beyond a person's hands if they were to stretch their arms out, like making human letter T, in any direction.  A person 6'2" would need more space than me at 5'7" for safe game play.The bad..so far I haven't really run into huge negatives. that bother me a lot.Battery life is shorter than I would hope for, about 2 hours.Makes me wish I had a full blown star trek holodeck.I recommend this, totally work the purchase.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 2 January 2020

one_reviews_text: Original Quest would not charge either to a defective battery or cable. Requested replacement and Amazon shipped me a new set before I even returned the defective set. Bravo to Amazon.The Oculus Quest is unbelievable and one has to see it to believe it. You can’t believe the technology!Fabulous product and highly recommended!!!!Having had this product for 3 months, I am downgrading my rating from 5 stars to 1 star. I have just received my second replacement of the Oculus Quest. The Oculus Quest has suddenly stopped charging on my first 2 units. Secondly, virtually everyone who owns the Oculus can’t cast the image from the headset to your iPhone as it is supposed to do.To make matters worse, there support system is horrible and there’s no phone number available for one to speak to a human about a technical problem.My opinion is that Oculus Quest was prematurely released with multiple bugs in the system. It needed months of work by R & D before it was released. Wouldn’t recommend buying until Oculus gets their act together and eliminates the bugs and develop a functional support system, which includes a phone number so someone with a problem can speak to another person.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 31 August 2019
review_title: Don’t Buy Now- To many problems!!!!

one_reviews_text: When I first received my headset, it was everything I could've expected: good graphics, responsive, immersive, etc. But now that I've had it for a month or two, I'm no longer satisfied.I mainly bought my headset to play VRchat. In this game, I was looking forward to being able to experience all different types of avatars and people. However, I can see almost no avatars in this game, and the headset overall is very glitchy.I have experienced many different glitches while using my Oculus Quest. The first glitch I ever encountered was that while playing VRchat, the game would either freeze and send me to my home room (in-game) or would just close itself. Then, I started having the issue of a complete black screen. People in-game could still hear and see me, and I could still hear them. But all I could see was a black screen. My biggest glitch so far is currently happening right now. When I try to turn on my headset, it acts as if it is brand new, automatically putting me into the "First Steps" simulation. When I get through it, I am put into my home, where I can see the space around me, but I cannot see my home screen. I can see my menu bar at the bottom, but any screen I try to view simply isn't there. When I try to manually access VRchat or any other game from the Oculus app on my iPad, the whole game crashes in the headset and ultimately puts me back into my home space without my home screen. I would not recommend this headset to anyone and I fully regret buying it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 11 November 2019
review_title: Good at first, but glitches increase with time.

one_reviews_text: If you're looking to get into VR (and you can look past the fact that Facebook owns Oculus), this is the headset to get. Being wire + PC free and still able to play really fun games is amazing. Beat Saber and other games are great workouts too!Pros:- Library is growing rapidly / Fun games- Most games are <= $25, All are $30 max- Game Refund policy- Developers listen and patch often- My 95 yr old Grandma thought it was cool- Guardian system- Sound is surprisingly good from headset- Easy to use the Store- Can play while you charge- FB is constantly updating and adding features like Oculus Link, hand tracking, etcCons:- 72 Hz refresh rate on lenses can make you sick on rail movement type games. Not as great as higher end sets obviously.- Casting drops often, even on 5Ghz- Facebook owns Oculus / What are they doing with the data?- Must use FB account to sign in for Social features (friends list, etc)- Foam facepad soaks up and holds sweat (get the VR facepad 3rd party accessory)
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 1 January 2020
review_title: Headset to Get for VR Beginners

one_reviews_text: First, the Oculus Quest is great.  Being untethered is the best way to experience VR.I've only played PSVR for comparison, and the Oculus is a technically superior experience in every way.  The tracking and motion controllers are more accurate and better designed, and the Guardian system is fantastic.  The only problem is that the headset itself is not nearly as physically comfortable an experience.  It takes much fiddling to get the fit and feel right, and even then, it's not what it should be.I feel that when you pay this much for an item that is otherwise well-made, comfort shouldn't be such an issue that you end up buying additional accessories to jury-rig your headset.  They could have put more thought into the weight distribution, and it feels like they just phoned-in the strap design.  Additionally, you're going to get sweat and oils from your skin on the face mask, and while the material of the Oculus is nice, it just absorbs all that grodiness.So far, I've purchased silicone mask covers for easy cleaning and materials to make a counterweight for the back of the strap.  It has helped, but it's not ideal.  I may try one of the padded strap rigs down the road, but I don't really want to spend the money for more accessories that may or may not help.  If you want an affordable counterweight example, I bought a small pouch of diving shot and used velcro loops to secure it to the strap.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 26 July 2020
review_title: Five stars for function, three stars for comfort

one_reviews_text: I used to own an Oculus Rift (OG retail) and sold it for a few reasons:1) The screen door effect was awful2) Setting up all of the sensors each time I wanted to use it was a massive choreThe Quest somewhat solves the first one and completely solves the second one. The Quest has a much higher resolution, and "inside out" tracking, which means no external sensors. I've read in reviews that people had better results with the external sensors, I completely disagree. I have WAY better results tracking the headset and the controllers with the "inside out" tracking on the Quest.A complaint I heard is that the Quest is heavy, I don't think it is at all. Another complaint is the loss of headphones using speakers instead, but I prefer this because if something happens in the "real world" (doorbell, etc) I'm not unresponsive and lost in the game.The new hand tracking (in beta) absolutely blew my mind, it's so cool and has a ton of potential for future games once it's refined.Being able to use the Quest as both standalone and as a Rift using the Link makes it more versatile. I've noticed that I need to be plugged into a USB 3.1 "Gen 2" port in order for the signal to stay reliable. The standard USB 3.0 (aka 3.1 gen 1) ports seem to cut out or have trouble connecting.To me the Quest is a massive leap forward, but there's still the nagging issue of putting a 1440p screen, a low resolution by modern standards, a millimeter from your eyeball. It does not have the razor sharp precision we're getting used to with 4K screens at a reasonable difference. Until we can get 4K or better yet 8K per eyeball, VR is not able to replicate the pixel fidelity of a console/PC game. That is a long way away, but the Quest proves innovation in other important areas are making the architecture of this technical far more accessible.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 10 February 2020

one_reviews_text: This works fine I guess, it's great that they can be used wirelessly or wired like a more traditional HMD. The question I have is more about the future of VR as a whole. The games for this thing are actually pretty terrible, so many stupid games where you stand in place and shoot things, or maybe you're on rails. The medium feels strangled by people refusing to accept any game that isn't 1st person when having games playable in 3D could be promising and make for a larger variety. The battery life hasn't been an issue since I usually get bored of the "experiences" long before they have time to run out. The interface is a bit annoying to navigate and it just feels like there's very little to do on it right now. VR as a whole is still hoping you'll be amazed by the ability to control things rather than having control just be part of what makes the game amazing. Hopefully in the future there will be cheaper headsets with less restrictions on what uses they have.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 31 March 2021
review_title: Wonder how well this technology will do.

one_reviews_text: Packaging :High quality. Everything is neat and pretty. Sounds funny, but this is the best nylon wrapping I have seen in my life.You feel this is a premium product when you unbox it.Usage and comfort:This is actually a lot of fun, the tracking is perfect, and some games are really fun. I think this is the first VR device that isn't a niche product - VR for the mass.The real issue with it is, as you can expect, the weight.  This thing is heavy and will hurt your face.  Sometimes you play with the straps and get to a sweet spot.. but mostly it will not be comfortable.  I still play, but I get really red marks on my face afterwards.Sound:Not as bad as people say, absolutely playable. But...one you try it with earphones , that's a one way ticket.Screen:Well.. although this is a high res OLED screen(s), this resolution is just not enough.  It's  OK and you will still have fun, and it will be immersive.. but the resolution is just not high enough at this stage.  It's all pixels (doesn't matter if you use Link or not - the resolution isn't there). You get used to it, but don't expect anything nearly close to what you see on a computer screen - maybe in 3-5 years or so.What I am bothered with is the significant amount of users with Dead Pixels out of the box.  Yes, I have them too.  Around 3 green pixels which never change.  Luckily they are not in the center so I kinda got used to ignore them.  Just a thing to keep in mind if you are a pixel peeper. Get it in a place which will let you replace it if you do get dead pixels.  BTW, google  it, there are a lot of users with the same issue.Prices:Games are generally too expensive for what you get.  No way around it.  The price of a simple VR game is usally around $30. You do get an option to ask for a full refund if haven't played it for more than 2 hours.I'm not sure I can recommend games here as Amazon might not approve this review if I do so..I won't.Conclusion:Really cool device - totally fun.Just be sure to know that you might get dead pixels , the resolution is much lower than what you would expect form a 2020 gaming device, and it is very front heavy.Are there any wireless alternatives to the Quest?  Not at this time.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 28 January 2020

one_reviews_text: Love it!Pro'sFairly easy set up.High Fun FactorWow!Everything from packaging to set up to buying and installing apps is very smooth.Battery has long life.The Guardian (holo-deck like grid that you set up to be your boundary is super cool to set up and works great!)Con'sHeadset isn't flush on my face (big cheekbones) so I have to crank it tight to get a snug fit. (no light leaking in)Head gets sore after about an hour of use. (I think this is the norm for all VR headsets)I've been waiting several years to buy a VR set ever since they announced them. I think this is the one to make it big. The no cords, free to walk around is awesome and a game changer.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 22 May 2019

one_reviews_text: I purchased this device in July and spent a month trying to get it working, buying every suggested cable and card. I was able to get it working, using advice from other users because the tech support was over run and seemed to be giving marginally useful advice from a pre-set script.Following instructions, I bought the 80 dollar official cable that didn't work, and bought a special card to work with the cable that didn't work, and then bought another cable and some adapters and a splitter, I ended up returning all of that crap and buying a simple Anker USB 3.0, you'll see it referenced in other reviews I'm sure.Now with a working VR kit, I play for a month and all is fine. Except now Facebook has decided it wants to rebrand the Oculus name and take ownership, with a lot of software updates and drivers on desktop and inside the VR headset, all pointing you in the direction of logging in to and then using Facebook on VR. Which is fine and dandy, if it worked at all. Trying to play games leads to random disconnects from the computer, random lockups and freezes in the apps. Lots of other Oculus Quest users reporting similar issues, and no fixes.If you think this is a good deal, just be careful. If it gives you the slightest issue, don't trust the process, get your money back  otherwise you'll be trying to get technical service up to and beyond the time you can return it, and that suits Amazon just fine.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 6 October 2020
review_title: Beware: Oculus or Facebook will break it with an update in a month so you can't play it or return it

one_reviews_text: This headset is an amazing platform. Its inside out tracking works very well and the image quality is high. I love that you can choose to see the real world if you want and the room scale guardian makes me feel safe to not worry about my surroundings. And I love that it will remember your play area between uses. This is the first vr headset I have tried that makes me believe the platform is viable. And it accommodates my large IPD.The cons:- the headset is new so its library of apps is small- many of the apps are the same as other platform's just with bigger price tags- it's not yet compatible with the go library (but oculus claims it will)- its heavier then the go but the extra features make it worth it- there is no brightness adjustment so expect the rays of god. If you are technologically inclined you can side load an app to turn on blue light filtering which will help- the battery is a little small but I get why. The headset does not need more weight. Just plug in when using stationary apps
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 21 September 2019

one_reviews_text: This is my first VR headset, and frankly, it’s my first meaningful VR experience. I really like it overall. I’m impressed with the amount of content available and was pleased to learn that many of the Oculus entertainment apps (Netflix, Venues, Sling, etc.) are available for the Quest. The headset is comfortable overall, but it needs to be positioned pretty precisely or the images are a tad blurry.I think there’s definitely some room for improvement on battery life and the quality / clarity of the screen. I understand that they couldn’t necessarily offer top-of-the-line hardware at this price point, but I expected a little better in both regards. They do provide a very long power cord, but being tethered to a power cord defeats the purpose of a cordless headset.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 7 September 2019
review_title: Very Cool, but Room for Improvement

one_reviews_text: We got this because my son really wanted Beat Saber.  He loves video games and he can be plenty physically active if we're doing something he likes, but he's not into playing sports.  I wanted him to get more exercise.  He now plays Beat Saber pretty much every day.  He gets a great workout and always has to shower after 'cause he gets so sweaty!  He's told me about so many things in his health and mental state that have improved since he began exercising daily with this game.  It's really amazing.  As far as the system itself, it is very impressive.  So simple to use and setup.  He can take it anywhere, setup his perimeters, and begin playing right away.  The only downside is the face cover gets really saturated with sweat if you're playing an active game.  We ended up buying a couple extra covers that are probably vinyl and don't absorb sweat. Those were a good addition.  All the games are remarkably small compared to what I was expecting.  The 64 GB size has been plenty.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 8 October 2019
review_title: Excellent for fun and burning calories!

one_reviews_text: I'm surprised how much I actually like this VR headset!I bought this primarily for gaming and was a little hesitant because at the time of purchase there weren't that many titles that appealed to me (i like FPS type games), and this made the price seem high just to play some VR games (been to several VR game centers in Tokyo so love VR).  However, after getting the headset i realized, OMG, there is much more to the headset than just gaming!  Regarding the limited number of appealing titles, quite a few new games are added frequently.WHAT I LIKEMany Amazon Prime shows and movies can be watched (not all tho), as well as YouTube and Netflix (if you have a subscription).  What's especially cool about watching movies with the headset is it's like being in a large, plush movie theater with a huge screen in front of you!  You look around and see a dimly lit theater, but, once the movie gets underway, the virtual room goes dark with just a large screen in front of you.With the ability to orient the view, I can lay on the sofa or in bed and watch movies or TV programs.  This means watching movies and TV programs is no longer limited to which room the TV is located in!I'm enjoying the Boxing VR workout sessions.  There are a variety of workouts to chose from, and I can do them anytime in the comfort and privacy of my own home.  For the most part, I like the accompanying music selections and the different gym types add the experience.  The workout sessions do give me quite a workout!I didn't expect to have my own virtual home whenever I'm wearing the headset, and the homes are quite impressive.  Some of the views are Sooo impressive and/or relaxing, I feel like getting a beverage, sitting back and just enjoying the view!My fav game so far is Pistol Whip.  It's like being John Wick!  This is an exciting, fast-paced game, which is a workout in itself!You can have the best of 2 worlds; Quest and Rift.  The Quest is an untethered device with the option to tether and have access to Rift games.Since the headset is self-contained and not tethered to a PC, it can be taken anywhere you go for gaming, TV, movies, workouts, etc.WHAT I DON'T LIKEThe headset has some weight to it, so after a while you start to feel the weight.  I've read Facebook will produce in the future a lighter weight headset.The games aren't cheap!  I purchased a couple of titles "right off the bat", and I regretted it.  I recommend before purchasing a game, checkout the reviews and watch previews on YouTube to have a good idea if it's something you'll enjoy.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 3 February 2020
review_title: Like it more than I thought I would  . .

one_reviews_text: I had never peeked inside a VR headset before buying this sight unseen.  I had read a lot of negative reviews of VR over the years, so I wasn't expecting much.  This probably contributed to my "holy s***" reaction to my first 5 minutes going through the First Steps tutorial.  The Quest VR is really a new kind of human experience.  I was truly blown away by home convincing the VR effect is.Now that I've had about 10 days with it, I thought I'd write a review.  The "omfg, wow" factor has worn off a little bit, but this is still a remarkable technology that really does transport you into a different realm for a short time.  I have picked it up every day I've had it, and so has everyone else in my family.There are some imperfections.  There is sometimes some glare in the lenses, or other optical deficiencies that detract from the experience.  But for the most part, it is an amazing effect.  "Running around" by using the controllers makes me motion sick in less than a minute.  I can't do that, so that limits the things I'm able to do a little bit.  But there's still plenty to do that feels very comfortable.  The Beat Saber game is a nice meditation.  The "Thrill of the Fight" game is a surprisingly good workout that has me huffing and puffing in no time.  There isn't a huge library of games, but there's enough good quality stuff right now to tide me over until the library expands, which I'm sure it will.Is it worth $400?  I would say it is.  There's more tech here than in a quality mobile phone that costs $400 and up.  It's a worthy addition as a "game console" in the same price range.If you've been waiting for VR to "make sense" in terms of price and performance and experience, the time is now.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 7 February 2020
review_title: It's not perfect, but 4 stars doesn't seem right either

one_reviews_text: Most reviews that have anything bad to say about the Quest say that it's not as good as HTC or Rift. Well, I say the Quest is amazing and they should shut their rich mouths. Not everyone can afford a massive gaming rig to run those headsets. The Quest has given me the opportunity to experience VR, which is something I've dreamed of doing since I was 5 (and I'm old)! The video quality is adequate, the sound is incredible, and the immersion is a religious experience. My only complaints are that it's a bit front-heavy after a while, and the battery lasts about 2-3 hours of constant gameplay. Neither of those issues make me regret my purchase. Once I get some more money saved up, I'm going to buy another one so my wife and I can both play together! Thanks for this incredible experience, Oculus! I look forward to upcoming games and accessories.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 30 May 2019
review_title: First VR experience and couldn't be happier

one_reviews_text: This is my first VR rig (if you don't count Google Cardboard) and it is unbelievably good. I wanted to try VR and just the set up and "first look" app experience was enough to justify the price to me. I'm very excited to see where VR will go. I'm not a gamer, so I need more exploratory apps. I love Mission: ISS that lets me explore the space station - I feel like I'm there. Wander gives me Google Street View in 360, but the interface is a bit clunky. I wish there was Google Earth. I bought Sports Scramble and played it with a friend who lives 400 miles away. It was fun for a few days but now seems repetitive and gimmicky. First Flight was interesting for a couple of hours, then got boring for lack of new experiences. VR in Virtual Reality was interesting. I played through, but got tired of it towards the end. I've tried some of the chat room apps, but they seem populated with screaming and badly behaving 13 year olds. Rec Room has some interesting stuff, but is not intuitive to use and I do not want to watch a bunch of YouTube videos to figure out how to change the color of my "dorm room".UPDATE: I wanted to watch an Amazon Prime movie but found it was locked for "parental controls". But there are no parental controls in the Oculus. Turns out the only way to watch all the Prime content in the Amazon Prime app is to disable the "purchase pin" on your Amazon account. Now you can watch movies, but you are exposed to people buying digital goods on your account. Seems like Amazon should have spent less time on making their VR app cool and more time thinking through the mechanics of watching Prime - which is the main point.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 2 November 2019
review_title: Fabulous Experience - except for viewing Amazon Prime content

one_reviews_text: I just got this as my first VR set after researching the many options and I am so glad I chose the Quest.  I was completely amazed by VR when I first used the set.  It is very simple to set up and with the side and top of head straps, can fit any size/shape head.  The eye glasses insert also fits extremely wide glasses, so if you wear them, it is likely to fit yours without issue.  Pixelation is also not a huge issue, the graphics are clean and crisp.  Always make sure to play in a well lit room as the tracking can struggle in a dark or dimly lit room.The biggest issue with the Quest is its game and app library.  The system is fully capable of playing the Rift games, but they just aren't available yet.  You also cannot use Steam VR.  The exception to this is when you plug your Quest into a PC,  you can play the Rift and Steam library, but this defeats the purpose of having a standalone, portable set.  Beat Saber is also lacking the extensive library of custom music/map downloads and mods, but you can get around this by sideloading them onto it, using Sidequest (you can google some great guides on how to do this).The Quest is also missing many of the streaming services apps.  It includes YouTube VR and Netflix, but lacks Hulu, Disney+, HBO, and others.  You can use the web browser to watch from these companies however and there is also an inexpensive Virtual Desktop app so that you can stream movies and music from your PC.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 26 December 2019
review_title: A great VR set for the beginners and long time gamers alike

one_reviews_text: After having both first and second gen head sets I can safely say this is a game changer.  I played this thing in one night more that I did with the two other headsets combined - Why?  Because it's wireless. It has no base stations, has a huge (25X25) possibly playing area.  Yes you take a hit in the graphics, these are snapdragon processors and not Radeon Vegas and nVida RTXs, but trust me - the wirelessness more than makes up for it.  This will drive more VR specific hardware in the the near future. PLUS you can stream SteamVR games with almost no latency  - That is there SOME latency, but very minimal.  I've also started using it to replace my steady state and HIIT cardio work outs with PistolWhip (Using Deadeye and real gun handling) which is a hell of a work out, and BoxingVR and Thrill of the Fight are a hell of a workout too.  I'm able to get my heart rate peak in the 150s after about 20 minutes of good playing with weights on ankles, wrists, and a vest and that is no mean feat as I'm already pretty much an athlete already and it takes quite a bit to get my HR up that high and stay there.I really can't stress how much fun this thing is.  I play it every day now as part of my workout... a hell of a lot more fun than going out to jog or do HIIT.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 16 February 2020
review_title: This is what I've been waiting for...

one_reviews_text: I have been a fan of VR since trying it in 1992, and always dreamt that one day it would be possible to affordably have it at home.  After owning the PlayStation VR for more than a year, I thought that it was great to have, but still had some limitations about setup, wires, and freedom of movement.Enter the Oculus Quest!  Despite having less graphical power than it's PC or PSVR counterparts, it's relatively low cost and utter portability take VR into a whole new generation.  And Oculus seems to be continually updating and improving it with free updates that add significant new features, like hand tracking without a controller, and the ability to tether to a PC for the full PCVR experience!  This is honestly my favorite bit of tech that I've ever owned, and I would recommend this to anyone that is interested in Virtual Reality but was put off by the cost and technical hoops.  This is your entry point!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 15 October 2019

one_reviews_text: Dislike:The Oculus Quest library is pretty solid but the Quest versions of popular games, such as Beat Saber, are way behind the PC versions in terms of customization options and user-generated content. I am also kind of dubious of how closed the Quest system is and signs Oculus is more aggressively trying to monetize their store compared to Steam.Like:You can use the headset without a PC.This is great for stuff like YouTube watching, Tilt Brush, and many other apps where the Oculus Quest version is just as fleshed out as PC versions.This is a bargain at $400 retailLOVE:Wireless Virtual Desktop to run PC VR gamesYou can run Virtual Desktop to play PC VR titles wirelessly via wifi. Yes, there is noticeable input lag when things get intense but for most players and in most titles, it's not a problem at all.The wireless experience is so good and liberating my wife and I have mostly left the Valve Index to collect dust and play PC VR games via Virtual Desktop.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 29 July 2020

one_reviews_text: No video I saw did it justice you have to try it for yourself.ConsSweating and then sharing. Depending on what you play you will sweat so playing with friends is kind of nasty.Grab buttons are very sensitive. It will take a few days to get 100% comfortable with that controller. It’s different And there’s no glancing down to see where the buttons are obviously.Also having to adjust it on your face to have it properly sit for the clearest image is a little clumsy That again speaks to sharing it because once you get it perfectly set you really don’t wanna have to readjust it.Most games are very short. It does not mean bad But $10 for an hour or so ep of Vader??? Ok!  Because it was great and if I ever lose my mind I will tell stories about the time i met Darth Vader In person. The games are getting longer and better I so it definitely has a future. Those are gripes because all in all I highly recommend if you’re interested you’ll probably be amazed.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 17 June 2020

one_reviews_text: I've been excited about VR since the original Oculus rift was announced years ago. I've been to multiple "try VR" experiences including The Void. I've tried friends headsets and tested the waters with mobile Daydream VR.  The problem is that I'm a casual gamer and have refused thusfar to buy a high end gaming rig to play VR. The Oculus Quest is finally what I've been waiting for!This device has been a blast from day 1. Even my spouse has been blown away by Beat Saber. The quality is a slight downgrade over higher end units but I promise you that you won't miss it. The immersion is second to none and VR without cords is a dream come true.I cannot say enough good things about this unit but will try and be realistic. The fit and comfort of the unit is decent and isn't a problem for extended sessions with it seated properly. Definitely leaves marks on my cheeks though. There is a significant gap around the nose which bleeds some light. This was an initial concern of mine but after real use I've come to appreciate being able to quickly peek through this hole back to reality and it also helps with airflow. I get very hot and sweaty when swinging a lightsaber. The adjusting straps are simple and Intuitive enough for my less than tech savvy wife to pick up immediately.The catalog of games is excellent so far. I have ever been more immersed than when I stepped into the world of Vader Immortal. This VR headset has ruined all other forms of gaming for me. My Switch and Xbox are now collecting dust.Excellent replayability and so easy to hop in for a quick 20-30 minute session. The ability to avoid external sensors is truly a game changer.I am not one to trust Facebook but they absolutely killed this one. If youre interested in VR, then you should buy this. It's that simple.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 31 July 2019
review_title: This is what we've all been waiting for!

one_reviews_text: O.M.G! This is the neatest think since...well, I don’t know what!I purchased this set after trying it out at my Sister’s place a couple of weeks ago. I tried Beat Saber, Box VR and Sports Scramble and heaven help me, I was beyond hooked! I’d just started a diet and exercise regimen and was handling the diet part, but not so much the exercise. My Quest has changed all that.As this is my first VR, I don’t have anything to really compare it with, but I LOVE this system! To me (again, I’m a VR noob), the immersion is simply amazing. There is a “getting started” app already built in, and it REALLY helped me get acquainted with how the controllers work. Plus dancing with that adorable robot had me at the hello wave. 🥰Because I purchased primarily for the calorie burn apps, I haven’t tried any shoot ‘em up games, yet. This does EXACTLY what I purchased it for; it gets me off my lazy keister and exercising! My Apple Watch calories burned have been pretty much off the charts since I started using this, so mission accomplished. Had zero idea that getting my heart rate up would be so much fun!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 27 January 2020

one_reviews_text: Mine sadly arrived with a dead pixel in the right eye but thankfully it's impossible to see it during game-play and it only prevalent when turning the machine on or off or i'm in a pitch black environment.I was originally going to buy the Vive and had bought tons of PC VR games ahead of time in anticipation, then I heard that this headset could play PC VR games wirelessly and a wired option for PC VR would come out soon. So I took the risk and pre-ordered it.While there are a few compromises, it works FAR better than I could have hoped. fair warning ALVR may be free but it's kinda crap, bite the bullet and buy Virtual Desktop and then sideload it. the quality is better, fewer crashes and much less compression issues. (If you have good internet, don't waste your money on the link cable, the quality is very similar to Virtual Desktop.)The Quest store didn't have a lot when this headset first released but the quantity of great games now is very respectable.I tend to play Beat Saber and Recroom on the go and play Skyrim VR and Saints and Sinners in my home space.I'm so glad I spent 450 for this instead of 1000 for a Vive and wireless setup or even an Index I can only play in my house.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 22 February 2020
review_title: Better than I could have hoped for, and it just keeps getting better.

one_reviews_text: The quest is unexpectedly more immersive than I anticipated. After reading that they're using a Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 I thought that well it's a first gen thing. Surely they can use a better chip in succeeding generations. I can wait for it. What changed my mind is the recent update that allows for a link cable to connect to the PC. essentially converting this unit from a stand alone VR to an optional PC VR unit.  That meant that even if the hardware is replaced, I could still find a use for the headset as a backup PC VR Rig. Since I'm purchasing it in this time frame, Vader Immortal comes bundled with the quest. While there is a number of expensive apps you could buy, there are also a number of free apps you can get. Rec Room, Altspace, bait and a few others. Connecting online also gives you the option to play online VR games. There's easy access to these sites on the quest and I haven't had any trouble playing them. Watching video you can see the screen door effect but I still enjoyed watching futurama on Prime VR and found streaming video from my PC to be simple. I found myself breathless in some of the games which is what I wanted. A means to trick my body into some light exercise while having fun. Motion sickness is a problem when moving without teleporting. I had assumed it would be no different from looking at a monitor and moving with keyboard and mouse but the immersion factor does something weird and its easy to get disoriented. My advice is to keep your turns small and slow and take breaks. Over all I've had a lot of fun with it the first day and look forward to the tech improvements of the future.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 26 November 2019

one_reviews_text: I'm having so much fun with the Oculus Quest and I'm glad I got it when I did as it's not available for the foreseeable future.  My main reason for pulling the trigger was for Half-Life: Alyx.  With the Oculus Link cable I'm able to connect to my PC (yes, a wireless headset now as a wire) and get way more games to play albeit with a wire.  You get access to Oculus Rift games AND steam VR games.  A lot of the time I'll check to see if steam has the same game that Oculus Quest is selling so that I can just get it during a steam sale  for dirt cheap.  Yes, once again you'll be playing with a wire but you'll be able to get a buttload more games to play. It's very much well worth it.  I've yet to try side loading apps and streaming the PC games to my headset to avoid having to use a wire but it's definitely an option.Aside from gaming, there's other cool apps you can use. I connect to my PLEX server and watch movies, there's a sports app that lets you watch highlights as if you were on the floor with the athletes (very cool), Amazon has their own VR videos, Google Maps street view is so much fun to visit places around the world like the Vatican, Stonehenge, etc.It's a really awesome product and I just went with the smaller 64GB version because the games aren't really that big to begin with (1-3GB) and the PC games are playing off of your PC.  Mine came with Vader Immortal and it definiely blows everyone's mind when they try it. Get it right meow!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 11 February 2020

one_reviews_text: I had never used any type of VR before purchasing the Oculus Quest so I had no idea of what to expect.  I am not really impressed by electronics and am disappointed quite often so I was a bit wary of the Oculus.  However, once I turned it on and went through the 1st tutorial I was absolutely blown away!  This is the coolest device (by far) I have ever seen in my life.  I still can't comprehend how it can be so real and fun.  If you are on the fence, buy it--you will not be disappointed.I can't answer for PSVR/Rift users as I never used those headsets.Pros*An un-tethered VR experience.  You actually feel like you are in that world.  I still can't get over how real these games are.  In Vader, it literally felt like Darth Vader was right there.*Lots of great games*Quick to turn on and jump in*Great controllersCons*I wish the graphics were a bit more clear, but that is not realistic based on the specs/price of this unit (I would NOT get a PC-based VR instead of this---the games are so fun as they are)*The headset straps are not the greatest.  I find myself messing with them a bit
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 25 May 2019

one_reviews_text: Can barely write a review, left controller didn't work out of the box, so Oculus support had me send it in. Its been over a month ago. Would return to Amazon seller had I not dealt with Oculus direct and sent them the faulty piece. Now I'm stuck waiting for them. All they told me today is that its under investigation and I'll get an update when something new comes up... SO, review score is for Oculus Support as I have not yet been able to use device. Buyer beware, Oculus Support is terrible!!!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 13 August 2020
review_title: Buyer beware, Oculus Support is terrible!!!

one_reviews_text: I've tried other VR headsets. They have 2 big problems that interrupt the experience. The biggest is that there are wires. They are always on your mind because they're touching you and you don't want to trip over them or wrap them around you. It seems like a small thing, but it's not as it totally distracts you from enjoying VR. The second issue is that you can't see the walls, desks, etc. around you ... but you know you might hit them if you're not careful ... even though you can't see them. This is a distraction from enjoying the experience too, and it's potentially painful! The Quest solves both. No wires! It also lets you easily define a "safe space" in your room, and when you get close to an edge it shows you inside the VR view ... in other words, you can see it when you get close. It's very clever and works great. It feels like magic. :-)
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 2 October 2019
review_title: This is the best VR experience.

one_reviews_text: Had the Quest for 3 days. Returned it, while simultaneously ordering the S (which I received Saturday thanks to Prime One Day). Have a high end laptop (with a mini DP), but I was looking to replace my old Rift. Loved the idea behind the Quest, and it's no doubt, excellent hardware, but for me, it was too uncomfortable, and I saw some compromises being made with certain games in order to keep up with my original Rift's performance (did back and forth comparisons while my Rift was still connected). The screen was kick butt over the Rift, but I missed my Steam games and some of the Rift/S only (for now) games.If I didn't have a capable PC, the Quest would have been a no brainer (eventually, I would have purchased whatever I needed to make it comfortable). The S turned out to be everything I was hoping for. Comfortable as heck, smooth as silk gameplay, a beautiful screen which made the Rift seem blurry in comparison, and no longer a slave to sensors. I do miss the black level of the OLED Quest, but now I can sell off my old Rift. Still excited to see how the link cable turns out. I will always keep my eye on the Quest! One never knows....
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 12 November 2019
review_title: Awesome Tech with limitations, one being it's super uncomfortable.

one_reviews_text: Excellent product which is pretty easy to setup out of the box. As well as its use as a standalone VR set, it can also be connected to a PC and play PC VR games. The PC needs to be relatively high spec per Oculus' stated minimum requirements. There are instructions on the internet on how to setup the Quest for wired or wireless connection with a PC. On its own the Quest is already very immersive. With a PC playing Half Life Alyx it truly feels like the future has arrived.The Quest hardware is high quality and controllers are comfortable and intuitive. As important is the software and interface which are excellent and easy to use. Friendly enough so you can just pick up and play (assuming you at least have basic familiarity with your smart phone and home network), but also giving you ability to tweak more advanced settings if you want to.Overall, the package exceeded expectations, especially given the user-friendliness and versatility of not only the headset itself but also the accompanying software, software eco-system (needed for PC VR) and its price point.UPDATE (2020/8/30): I am reducing my rating from 5-stars to 3-stars. Originally, Oculus did not require purchasers to register with a Facebook account. Unfortunately, that policy has changed and in future all users will need to have a valid Facebook account to use this device. I personally do not feel comfortable having all my personal info vacuumed up by Facebook and hence cannot in good conscience maintain a 5-star recommendation. The hardware is good but in future all user activity and data will be logged by Facebook
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 19 June 2020
review_title: Simple to set up, excellent room scale wireless VR, great product all round

one_reviews_text: Update: 2019 Aug 14 : Casting to Chromecast Ultra 4k works with ~1second lag. Occasional freezes but continues.Used to play with Google VR using the phone but the lack of input made it more of a hype.Pro:The Oculus Quest with the two controllers is so much more immersive. Beat Sabre is a whole lot fun with it.There's no perceptible lag in the tracking of the controllers!The portability of it is amazing!I could see ray tracing of the the light glow from the lightsabre in Vader Immortal - so Real!Cons:Managed to cast to Chromecast Ultra with ~1 second lag. Occasional freezes but recovers.You can't record mixed reality videos at the moment with Liv, the Mixed Reality Capture (MRC) support announced by Oculus requires you to have an Oculus Rift for calibration on top of a video capture card.The controller's battery cover tend to slip open during play - especially Beat Sabre where you're swinging a lot, not so much for shooter games.To prevent controller battery cover sliding open or just accidentally throwing the whole controller itself, I highly recommend getting rubber sleeves for the controller, some folks use elastic bands. I've accidentally thrown it once as my hands got sweaty during gameplay.The screen door effect is visible in some games, not in others. *meh* on this one.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 11 August 2019

one_reviews_text: My only exposure to VR was the google cardboard which I hated. Made me nauseous, graphics were awful from a phone so never tried anything VR again. I heard so much about this item that I decided to get one for myself for Xmas. So glad I did. I'm now a VR addict and I'm an older gentleman. Games are amazing to play in the virtual world. Beat Saber is addicting.Screen door effect is there, but I don't really notice it much in games and is minimal. Graphics are fine, I'm sure with a Valve Index etc , the graphics are probably much better. But there's nothing wrong with the visuals with this.I'm now gonna get a computer tethered headset Vale/Rift S upgrade as soon as I can afford it. But this is great for quick playing and worth every cent. If you're someone like me who had only tried phone based options then you have to give this a try. And I'll always keep one of these around for the wireless option. Can't wait to see the next generation of this item. I will be buying one of those as well.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 16 January 2020
review_title: I LOVE it!!! You have to give this a try

one_reviews_text: Just got it in the mail today.  It took me about an hour to get it going with all the downloads and updates and all.  I already had the Oculus App because I have the Oculus Go, but it wouldn't bring up the Quest for headset to install.  So then I had to uninstall my Oculus App and reinstall the app.  To do that I got put in a long queue because everybody and is brother is trying to install their apps on opening day.  Then when I finally got it paired, I had to wait a while for the headset to update.My main beef is that Oculus didn't update the app I already had, so I wouldn't have to uninstall and then reinstall the app.I'm sure we'll have a lot of fun with it.  We've only just begun.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 21 May 2019

one_reviews_text: This is a truly ground-breaking device for VR. The price is acceptable for the experience you get from it and after attending the Oculus Connect 6 via Oculus Venues in VR, I think there is a bright future ahead. This is not just a toy or a gaming platform. This is a new way to consume content, be it surfing the net, socializing online, watching movies or YouTube and of course playing games. Oculus Connect 6 Day One presentations showed the business sector has some uses for it as well. Getting it now, is getting head start to the future of the media creation and consumption.As for the quality of the device itself - it is my first VR device (Google Mobile VR not counting) so I have nothing to compare it to and perhaps this is a good thing. I understand that the graphic quality is not up to par with the Rift and Vive counterparts, but what it has is enough for the brain to be completely fooled into believing the virtual environments it creates. It's not just my opinion. I took it to work and half my office ordered one the same day. They all were blown away. This ability alone, to take it on the road, anywhere is worth its money already.I've read that it felt heavy for some people but I didn't notice it at all, neither has my wife and my 11-years old kid. The little one 6-years old did complain a bit. The sound quality could be better though again we didn't mind. I bought special earbud earplugs for it (not the original as they are quite expansive) and it, apparently, didn't make that much of a difference. I understand that quality earphones for Oculus Quest have not materialized yet on the market.I really recommend this product and I really recommend reading about what Facebook and Oculus has in their mind for its future (hands tracking in software, completely free in November 2019). This is a great purchase for anyone. A glimpse into the future and fantastic entertainment value for its money.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 29 September 2019
review_title: A ground-breaking consumer device. Excellent experience!

one_reviews_text: I own, in addition to the Quest, the Oculus Go and the Lenovo Mirage Solo.  Both the latter two headsets will usually keep a pretty good charge for at least a couple weeks when turned off.  However, every time I charge the Quest and then unplug the charger (which I did last night) the next time I want to use it won't start and gives me a  low battery warning.  I just tried to use it and it happened again.  They need to fix this!  So my only option is to always leave plugged into the charger which I really don't like to do.  I've tried turning it on after a charge and doing a shut down. Doesn't help.  The battery still drains out in a a few hours.  As much as I like the Quest, and I do like it, a lot, I would not have bought it knowing what I know now.Update. My battery is now keeping a charge just fine while not in use even over a couple of weeks. I might add at the latest update to the headset is marvelous. It’s like I got a whole new headset. I’m really pleased with how they continue to work on an upgrade my purchase.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 27 August 2019
review_title: Standby battery life OK now. I have revised my review

one_reviews_text: This was my first VR experience, and initially, I was just blown away.  It's amazing how real it feels.  That said, there just aren't good, fun games to play.  After Beat Saber, there really wasn't much interesting to me, and Beat Saber really lacked a good variety of songs without spending absurd amounts of extra money on DLC.  I did purchase 7-8 games, and there are a bunch that are cool, but none really have great staying power after Beat Saber.  Almost everything in this feels like a novelty rather than a real game.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 1 March 2020

one_reviews_text: I have zero experience with VR and paid no attention to it until I started seeing some reviews for quest. I didn’t expect people to be saying such good things about vr but from what I saw in the reviews, being a wireless untethered device with solid motion tracking, my interest grew. I decided to order one and upon receiving it, had read about a lot of the games, pros, cons. My initial experience has been impressive to say the least. This technology is pretty cool and it blew me away with the interaction you have with the hand controllers. Being a console gamer since NES, I had never played anything like this before. It is a game changer for sure. Best saber, superhot vr, and drop dead are all pretty excellent games that I like. I’ve tried a few others and while they are good, the price might not justify their worth. You can tell that this technology will continue to improve as the resolution isn’t the greatest and the battery life a bit short. That would be my biggest complaint...the resolution. Considering $400 can get you a 4K console, the quest is obviously not that and a bit pixely, but by no means is it a deal breaker and doesn’t negate the fun factor. From what I understand that’s the compromise being made in order to be completely wireless, which is fantastic. I can’t imagine being tethered to a high end computer (that I don’t have) while playing these games. At $400 plus the cost of games, it’s a bit steep, and unless oculus continues with a steady stream of strong titles, not sure how long the wow factor will last...it’s incredible technology that will depend on a continual release of new fun games. Just know you won’t be getting console/pc quality resolution. I expect the inevitable quest 2 or quest 3 will be the real game changers, but for now this is an extremely fun device worth giving a shot if you have the money to spend.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 20 June 2019

one_reviews_text: Facebook forces you to get a Facebook account to fully use it. Without it forget about playing online or using Oculus Venues. So basically if you want to use your $400-$500 device you also have to relinquish your privacy and give them your personal information or go through the struggle of creating a fake account.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 31 January 2020
review_title: If you do not have a Facebook account you cannot fully use it

one_reviews_text: The Oculus quest is taking Virtual Reality to the next level. If you only get one app, make it Beat Saber.Beat Saber is the reason I purchased the Oculus Quest. I was playing on my Oculus Rift CV1, and I was thinking, if there were no wires this would be perfect. Boom! Oculus Quest!There is a great selection of game and apps to choose from now that the Quest has been out for a while.Now, with the Oculus link capabilities, you can connect your Quest to your PC, and enjoy much higher quality games. I’m playing Alien Isolation with the Mother Mod, and is is awesome!The reason I took off one star is because while the audio is functional, it is a total letdown compared to the Oculus Rift. Those headphone are amazing compared to what they went with in the Quest. It’s doable, but barely. I’m using some iPhone earbuds until I find something better.  Don’t buy the Oculus earbuds or similar. They don’t produce sound that is worth the money.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 9 December 2019

one_reviews_text: Excellent technical product, but it is super proprietary.  Only games Facebook (owner of Occulus) allows in their store are playable.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 13 September 2019

one_reviews_text: If you've used an Oculus Rift on PC, the experience is almost identical to that, but with a slight downgrade in graphics. Fewer special effects, lower-resolution textures, etc. But if you compare the actual interaction and playability within games, the experience is almost 100% the same, and I'd argue considerably better given the wire-free nature of the product. Further, the fact that I can press a button and jump into VR means that I can use the Quest in short stints here and there, without firing up a PC to do it, making it 100x more likely I'll use it at all. This right there is the kicker that makes it even remotely possible that my wife would try it - it's so easy, she can throw it on, fire it up, and get to playing Beat Saber or what-have-you.Battery life is good (2+ hours so far), game selection is good and improving, responsiveness and tracking accuracy is perfect, as far as I can tell, and it even remembers the locations and boundaries I draw for the play space! I'm blown away! Now make a 2.0 with a modern SOC (preferably a new Nvidia Tegra chip) and we're in business!If only this were available 6 months ago! Alas, it's available now, and I can't recommend it enough.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 24 May 2019

one_reviews_text: Exceeds my expectations. The package arrives with a very premium look and feel. It was very easy to setup but I did watch a few Youtube videos so I could get up and running as quick as possible. Vader Immortal was my first purchase and it does not dissappoint. It is almost as realistic as the VOID experience at Disney Springs. Wielding a lightsaber in the game works flawless. Tried the other apps and things like Netflix and Amazon Video were interesting to sit an enjoy watch TV or movies. Dont think I would do it that often because the quality isnt as good as my own TVUPDATE - 8-6-18 After 1 week I have bought a few games to go along with this from the Oculus store. Battery life is about 2.5 hours so you need to buy an external 10000+ mAh for longer sessions. I suggest getting rechargeable AA batteries for the Touch hand controllers. Already went thru 2 sets of batteries the first week. I have watched movies from my Plex server thru the web browser. Firefox VR was just released and works pretty good as well. Good assortment of free content. Download SideQuest to install mods and other content not available in the Quest store. I am using Virtual Desktop  to access my Steam VR content. I couldnt get other free solutions working like ALVR. Steam VR content is not flawless, you do get a little bit of stutter every now and again. Possibly a really good NightHawk gaming Wifi router would solve that issue. I have AC1700 Netgear router.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 2 August 2019

one_reviews_text: I definitely recommend this device for people interested in checking out the VR experience. In 2016 I spent a lot of time using an HTC Vive in college. In 2017, I decided to purchase an Oculus Rift and I used it for architectural design using custom software. In 2018, I bought 11 Oculus Go's in order to use them to teach VR development at the college level. In May 2019, I purchased the Oculus Quest and I really love it.Fifty years from now historians will look back and may well consider this the watershed device for VR. The Rift and Vive required an expensive computer and were tethered with cables. The Go is only 3 degrees of freedom and one controller. The Quest is the first Minimum Viable Product in my opinion. Here's why: It has a good price point, the graphics quality is just good enough to eliminate the screen door effect, no wires, it's very comfortable, the processing power is just at the bottom level to be good enough for a very good experience and the tracking seems flawless to me. I highly recommend this device with one caveat... Oculus is restricting independent development on the device which might keep the level of quality higher but will ultimately suffocate innovation at a critical time for VR. There just aren't enough things to do with it beyond shooting things. I hope this is useful.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 12 June 2019
review_title: The first truly viable VR device for the masses

one_reviews_text: In the first 30 days of using the Quest, I lost 15 pounds and felt like I was 35 again (I'm 57). I started out at 240 pounds. My knees had gotten to the point that I had to go up and down stairs one step at a time using my right leg. After 2 weeks of beat saber, I was able to go up and down stairs like they were nothing and was already feeling 10 years younger. By the end of the first 30 days, I was kicking ass and taking names. My daughter and grandkids said I looked like I was a ninja when I played beat saber. Then Thanksgiving hit. I quit working out, ate way too much and the next thing I knew it was the 10th of January and I had not only gained all my weight back but even more, as I was now 245 pounds. I was back to taking the stairs one step at a time. I'm back on the Quest again, and back to where I feel like I'm 20 years younger again. It's now February 9th and I'm back down to 223 pounds. The thrill of the Fight makes me lose the most weight I think as it is a High-Intensity Workout. But, my favorite now is Pistol Whip. I like to play two ways. For the most aerobic workout, Iike to put it on dual guns and the hardest setting and go as hard as I can. I can beat all the levels doing this without dying but it's hard and you'll have to move your ass to not die. The other way is to truly challenge myself. I usually do this at the end of my workout. Put on deadeye, where you have to be accurate and get it on. Pistol Whip is so much like being John Wick, I started actually thinking it was saying hello Mr. Wick instead of Pistol Whip at the beginning. You'll notice the John Wick references as soon as you hit start. Great game and within 30 minutes I'm soaking wet with sweat. Don't have a large area? I play all kinds of places including sitting down. You wouldn't believe how much you can sweat and how tired you can get after an hour of sitting and playing some of the games. The only think I can suggest is to get into it full swing. I watch a lot of people who barely move in VR, I guess because they're scared, but you've got to get involved and make those hard shots, jump to the side, and duck all the way down if you really want to benefit.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 10 February 2020
review_title: Best Exercise Equipment You'll Ever Buy!!!

one_reviews_text: While the Oculus Quest had a bit of a rocky start for me, with some graphical glitching and screen tearing, those issues have since been patched out. Even with those issue though, they didn't hamper my complete amazement and fasination with using the headset. Having tried PC VR before, the lower graphic quality is noticable, but matters little as the experience is still thoroughly enjoyable, and the lack of any wires to contend with is very liberating. If you have ever considered trying out VR, or just want a headset of your own and can't afford a good enough gaming PC, I cannot recommend the Quest enough. Honestly, even if i did have a gaming pc, the Quest might still be my first choice.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 15 June 2019

one_reviews_text: It took some years to finally decide to go with this VR set.  The resolution is pixelated since you are so close to the screen when wearing it, but not a gamechanger for me.  The benefits outweigh the cons for a completely wireless headset.  Many of the games and videos are short, but an awesome workout when you have the space to use it.  This headset may be a little weighted for some so compare to other models to see what works for you.  Ultimately, the latest update to use hand recognition is great so the controllers are not required for some navigation.  Great way to save on controller batteries.  I will more than likely respond with more info after longer use but really like this device.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 27 December 2019

one_reviews_text: The quest has been the go to for many consumers for the past year. With frequent updates and amazing support from Oculus this headset is a must buy!I recently received mine on June 13th and have been amazed since powering it on. Before purchasing I tried my friends Rift S and found that I did not get motion sick like I thought I would. After researching several products I decided the quest was the best bang for my buck and I wasn't wrong!Once it showed up I powered it up and even though is has a lower refresh rate, at 72Hz vs the Rift S i previously tried at 80Hz. I still did not feel the effects of motion sickness. That was a major concern for me and I am happy to report that its superb in curbing motion sickness, for me anyway.The astounding amount of updates and new software capabilities of this machine has been staggering, considering that is has only been out for just over a year. The fact that you can use it wirelessly and tethered to your PC opens up a massive library of games you can't get on other devices. With the quest you can utilize the quest store for headset specific games, the oculus store for Rift and Rift S games, and the steam store for even more content to digest.All in all with today's current tech and the plethora of abilities that this headset currently possesses i would highly recommend to anyone who is currently in the market for a VR system.Thank you Oculus for making such a great  debut, and then actually spending time improving upon your efforts tbe way you have!! Keep up the great work!!!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 18 June 2020

one_reviews_text: This is my first VR experience and I've never done anything like it.  Serious gamer my whole life and this thing will really change the game.  When I first put the headset on....some light was coming through the bottom and I was like "oh this isn't going to be immersive at all".  And then the demo started and you're just instantly transported.  Just incredible.  Everything just....works.  No problems at all, great variety of games.  LOVE
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 23 November 2019

one_reviews_text: I've been a VR enthusiast since the nineties, but only with the current resurgence have I been able to really explore it. I've owned most of the major platforms to come out over the last few years, I recently picked up the Go as a pick-up-and-play solution, but wound up returning it to get this instead. As much as I enjoy the PC VR experience, I have to say it's a lot easier to just pick up the Quest and go to it.Currently, my favorite game is Moon Rider, a free web-based "Beat saber" clone with a punch mode which has become my nightly exercise. You know you're on to a winner when you have to pace yourself on exercise. The graphics are not as good as PC, admittedly, but they are good enough, even at these early days. Give it a year and devs will be really pushing the hardware.Basically, VR has been waiting for a fully untethered and portable room-scale solution, and this is really doing the job. I think of it as the Model T of consumer VR: not the first, but the one that will bring the technology to the general public. This is a definite step in the right direction, and a lot of fun.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 5 June 2019

one_reviews_text: I like the Quest, and I have a Go and like both however my problem lies in Oculus procedure to return content. They make it very difficult to look up the procedure and have links to instructions that do not work. When you finally do figure it out and go to your orders history page there is no way to make a return request. I get the feeling this is by design, and it bring the integrity of Oculus to question.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 14 September 2019
review_title: Claims to allow you to return content but then does not support it.

one_reviews_text: Worth every penny! This thing has exceeded my expectations. We use it daily for exercise. I use the Supernatural app, which costs extra, but it’s so fun! It’s perfect for someone who hasn’t worked out in years & doesn’t have time to go to a gym. It’s helped my 7 year old & 5 year old tremendously with coordination, & it’s added a lot of fun to an otherwise difficult year! I’m a mom of young kids, not a “gamer”, & even I think this is worth every penny. The only downside is that most of the apps/games cost $$ like they would on another game system, so know that you’ll probably end up spending more $ after you buys this.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 7 September 2020
review_title: Great purchase for anyone, even for moms!

one_reviews_text: Everything about the quest is awesome except these few things that could be a deal breaker.The resolution needs to be increased, small details are hard to make out which has my eyes almost constantly trying to focus.The weight of the headset gets quite uncomfortable after 30min-1hr. Neck muscles are tired and sort of gives you a headache. Maybe that goes away after a few weeks?The games on the quest don't feel like full titles like on PS4Other than that I love it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 27 July 2019

one_reviews_text: Was cov19 going on It's nice to have this. I've been watching daily on Amazon and they sell out fast unless you want to pay way more money elsewhere just wait they'll come back in stock. So when I ordered it it said arriving in 3 weeks. Day after I ordered it they came in and they sent them out and I had it in about 3 days. It was quicker than 3 weeks. But I am very pleased I love it I got the 64 gig The games you can store is more than enough storage. I'm happy I don't know what else to say read more reviews but I'm happy with mine. The battery life could be a little better but you know all I did was took some rubber bands and attached a little power block on the back It actually works out good got some more life to it for battery life. But this machine will blow your mind.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 11 July 2020
review_title: I didn't think it would blow my mind but it did I love it

one_reviews_text: So just now I was surrounded by five dudes with guns when my friggin' right controller ran out of battery, leaving me to take out all of these red jerks with only my left hand. After running out of ammo from my terrible aim, I was left crawling around my apartment floor for cover from their fire, cracking up, scrambling to find ninja stars and vases and such to finish off the last couple enemies... and I succeeded. Super hot? Most definitely.I haven't been this amazed with a video game system since I was in the 6th grade and played Mario 64 for the first time. This device is a game changer, with everything you need for immersive VR right out of the box, no wires or sensors, and no motion sickness. Everybody needs to try this.
